1 | The National Investigation Agency (NIA) attached immovable property and land at Chatra District of Jharkhand belonging to Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘commander’ identified **Read more...** The National Investigation Agency (NIA) attached immovable property and land at Chatra District of Jharkhand belonging to Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘commander’ identified as Gopal Singh Bhokta, reports OneIndia News on June 2. An inter-college and 245 decimals of land at Chatra District of Jharkhand were attached by NIA. TPC ‘commander’ Gopal Singh is involved in raising illegal money through extortions and illegal collection of levy. **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Security Forces (SFs) arrested an individual identified as Jagdev Yadav alias Jato Yadav, accused in 16-year-old Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] case from Vishanpur village of Charkapathar Police Station in Jamui District of Bihar on June 1, repor **Read more...** Security Forces (SFs) arrested an individual identified as Jagdev Yadav alias Jato Yadav, accused in 16-year-old Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] case from Vishanpur village of Charkapathar Police Station in Jamui District of Bihar on June 1, reports Hindustan. Security Forces (SFs) comprising of Bihar Police and Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB) formed a team and arrested him from his house during the raid. Jagdev Yadav is first accused in Naxal case number 38/2005 registered at Sono Police Station, said Station House Officer (SHO) Abdul Haleem **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Two Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres including a woman were killed in an exchange of fire with Security Forces (SFs) in the dense forest near Bhandarpal village in Kondagaon District of Chhattisgarh on June 1, reports Free Press J **Read more...** Two Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres including a woman were killed in an exchange of fire with Security Forces (SFs) in the dense forest near Bhandarpal village in Kondagaon District of Chhattisgarh on June 1, reports Free Press Journal. Based on information about the presence of CPI-Maoist cadres belonging to the North Kanker-Mainpur Division Coordination Committee in the jungles of Rajpur, Bhandarpal and Timnar villages along the Kondagaon-Kanker District border, the team of the Chhattisgarh Police's District Reserve Guard (DRG) carried out an anti- Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] operation leading to an encounter with CPI-Maoist cadres on June 1. After the encounter was over, the Police team searched the area and found two bodies of CPI-Maoist cadres, including a woman, clad in uniform. Police recovered one Self Loading Rifle (SLR), 303 rifle and three 12 bore rifles along with a huge cache of arms and ammunition and other materials from the site. Police believe that few more CPI-Maoist cadres could have been injured in the action and search in a nearby area is underway to arrest the CPI-Maoist cadres, who had escaped from the spot, said Inspector General of Police (IG), (Bastar range) Sundarraj P **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘sub zonal commander’ identified as Nunuchand Mahto alias Tiger alias Gandhi alias Netaji, carrying a reward of INR 5,00,000 over his head, has surrendered before the Police in Giridih District of Jharkhan **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘sub zonal commander’ identified as Nunuchand Mahto alias Tiger alias Gandhi alias Netaji, carrying a reward of INR 5,00,000 over his head, has surrendered before the Police in Giridih District of Jharkhand on June 1, reports UNI. Speaking to the media after his surrender, Nunuchand said that he was relieved after returning to the mainstream and also urged other CPI-Maoist cadres to follow the same. He has joined CPI-Maoist in 2008. **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘sub-zonal commander’ identified as Uday Oraon was arrested by Police at Murhu-Karcha Chhapar Toli village under Pesrar Police Station in Lohardaga District of Jharkhand, reports Dainik Jagran on June 2. U **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘sub-zonal commander’ identified as Uday Oraon was arrested by Police at Murhu-Karcha Chhapar Toli village under Pesrar Police Station in Lohardaga District of Jharkhand, reports Dainik Jagran on June 2. Uday Oraon belongs to Dalam (armed squad) of Ravindra Ganju, the regional ‘commander’ of CPI-Maoist, who carries a reward of INR 1.5 million over his head. The arrested CPI-Maoist sub-zonal commander, Uday Oraon is involved in killing of Munshi, road construction worker under Pesrar Police Station, kidnap and killing of a villager in Mungo in Serendag Police Station area, set ablaze of many vehicles and other Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] incidents. Intelligence officials along with Police teams have interrogated Uday separately and started work on the Naxal incidents. During the interrogation, Uday had provided information related to the CPI-Maoist outfit including planting series bombs in the forests of Lohardaga District. It has given important information to the Police about weapons, pressure bombs, cane bombs, landmines, Naxal squads. Uday Oraon has been wanted in dozens of cases in Lohardaga, Gumla and Latehar Districts of Jharkhand. **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Police have identified Two Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres including a woman, who were killed in an encounter with Security Forces (SFs) in the dense forest near Bhandarpal village in Kondagaon District of Chhattisgarh on June 1 a **Read more...** Police have identified Two Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres including a woman, who were killed in an encounter with Security Forces (SFs) in the dense forest near Bhandarpal village in Kondagaon District of Chhattisgarh on June 1 as Aasu Korcha (20), resident of South Bastar and Reena Naretti (27), wife of Ramesh Hupendi, reports Nai Dunia on June 2. Both these slain CPI-Maoist cadres were carrying a reward of INR 5, 00,000 each on their heads. Both the slain CPI-Maoist cadres were involved in the arson in Kusanmari area under Dhanora Police Station in March and several other Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] incidents in the area. The deceased women, Reena Naretti, who is from Tamoda village in Amabeda of Kanker District, have been involved in several CPI-Maoist incidents like spreading panic and working with Naxal outfits. More than half a dozen offences have been registered under sections of murder, attempt to murder, arson, including explosives, arms act, UAPA and IPC. **Read less...** | | June - 2 June - 3 | Cadres of the Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), demanded ‘levy’ (extortion money) from Nityanand Das, Block Development Officer (BDO) of Manatu, after which he registered an FIR a **Read more...** Cadres of the Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), demanded ‘levy’ (extortion money) from Nityanand Das, Block Development Officer (BDO) of Manatu, after which he registered an FIR at Manatu Police Station in Palamu District of Jharkhand on June 3, reports UNI. The BDO in his complaint said that on Wednesday (June 2) morning around 10 AM he had first received the call but since the voice was not clear a second call came to him. From the other side, the man identified himself as Nagina Ji of the TPC and demanded money for running the organisation over which the BDO had said that he will speak with the seniors in this regard and had cut the phone. In his complaint, the officer also said that between 12.12 PM to 12.17 PM on Thursday (June 3) he had received five calls on his number for ‘levy’ but the amount was not specified. **Read less...** | | June - 2 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) Communication ‘Chief’ in Bijapur District of Chhattisgarh and senior leader of Dandakaranya Special Zonal Committee (DKSZC), identified as Sobroi alias Gaddam Madhukar alias Mohan, carrying a reward of IN **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) Communication ‘Chief’ in Bijapur District of Chhattisgarh and senior leader of Dandakaranya Special Zonal Committee (DKSZC), identified as Sobroi alias Gaddam Madhukar alias Mohan, carrying a reward of INR 800,000 over his head and one CPI-Maoist courier were arrested by Telangana Police on Peddammagadda Cross Road close to Mulugu Road in Warangal District of Telangana on June 2, reports Free Press Journal. Gaddam Madhukar and a courier were arrested during a vehicle-check by Police. Madhukar was suffering from Covid-19, had come to Warangal for the treatment with the help of the courier, a minor. Several cases against him were pending in the Police Stations of Bastar Division. Madhukar who hails from Kumaram Bheem Asifabad District in Telangana had joined the Sirpur Dalam (armed squad) of the then People’s War Group (PWG)) in 1999. The Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] outfit later shifted him to DKSZC and since then, he was involved in several offences including killing of Police personnel and snatching away their weapons. The CPI-Maoist courier went to Venkatapuram forest area in a car and was bringing Madhukar to Hanamkonda for admission in a hospital. When Police searched the vehicle at the check post, Madhukar was found hiding in the car’s boot. Police arrested both of them and seized INR 88,000 cash. Madhukar was later admitted to a hospital for treatment, said Warangal’s Commissioner of Police, Tarun Joshi. Madhukar informed to Police that a large number of senior Maoist cadres are suffering with COVID-19. But the CPI-Maoist is not allowing them to go outside for better treatment. The cadres in exceptional cases are allowed to go outside for getting better treatment, only after their health condition turns worse. Maoist leaders said found to be infected with Covid- 19 include Telangana State Committee Secretary Yapa Narayana alias Haribhushan alias Lakma, Telangana State Committee members Bade Chokka Rao alias Damodar, and Kankanala Raji Reddy alias Dharmanna alias Venkatesh, DKSZC members Katta Ramchandra Reddy alias Vikalp and Kunkati Venkataiah alias Vikas, DKSZC spokesperson Mula Devender Reddy alias Masa Dada, South Bastar Divisional Committee (DVC) Secretary, Muchaki Ungal alias Raghu alias Sudhakar, and other CPI-Maoist cadres Kodi Manjula, Pusam Padma and Kakarla Sunitha, added Tarun Joshi, reports The Hindu on June 2 **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Chhattisgarh Government has withdrawn 594 criminal cases, including more than 100 CPI-Maoist related cases against tribals in Chhattisgarh, reports The Times of India on June 4. A court acquitted all the accused after reviewing the recommendation of **Read more...** Chhattisgarh Government has withdrawn 594 criminal cases, including more than 100 CPI-Maoist related cases against tribals in Chhattisgarh, reports The Times of India on June 4. A court acquitted all the accused after reviewing the recommendation of a high-level committee. The high-level seven-member committee under the chairmanship of Justice A K Patnaik was constituted in December 2018 by Chhattisgarh State Government headed by Chief Minister (CM) Bhupesh Bagheal to review the criminal cases lodged against innocent tribals in the Maoist insurgency affected Districts. The committee had recommended the withdrawal of 627 cases and based on the recommendation, 594 cases have been withdrawn from the court, benefiting 726 persons. Similarly, 365 Maoist-related cases were identified by the Police department for speedy trial in the courts, in which 218 undertrials were acquitted in 124 cases. Of these, 36 people were acquitted in 24 cases in Dantewada District, 47 people in 44 cases in Bijapur District, nine people in seven cases in Narayanpur District and nine in three cases in Kondagaon District, six people were acquitted in one case in Kanker District, 109 people in 44 cases in Sukma District and two accused in one case in Rajnandgaon District. **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) in a pamphlet have again strongly opposed the excavation work of the Surajgarh Iron Ore project and warned the workers involved in excavation work to be killed in Gadchiroli District of Maharashtra, report **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) in a pamphlet have again strongly opposed the excavation work of the Surajgarh Iron Ore project and warned the workers involved in excavation work to be killed in Gadchiroli District of Maharashtra, reports Sakal on June 4. The letter of Naxals \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] was found at Surajangarh Iron Mineral Hill. In the past, CPI-Maoist cadres have set ablaze 83 vehicles in the area opposing this project. **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Police arrested Nath Ganjhu alias Bhagirath, an ‘area commander’ of the Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), from Bharkudwa village under Lawalong Police Station area in Chatra Distri **Read more...** Police arrested Nath Ganjhu alias Bhagirath, an ‘area commander’ of the Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), from Bharkudwa village under Lawalong Police Station area in Chatra District of Jharkhand on June 3, reports UNI. An US-made rifle, one .315 bore rifle, 30 cartridges of different guns, Naxal \[Left Wing extremism, LWE\] literature and TPC pamphlets have been recovered from the possession of Bhagirath. **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Police recovered two fake AK-47s, CPI-Maoist uniforms, and a bag from a forest near Dugeli village under Bacheli Police Station limits in Dantewada District of Chhattisgarh, reports Ommcom News on June 4. Police team visited the village and had discu **Read more...** Police recovered two fake AK-47s, CPI-Maoist uniforms, and a bag from a forest near Dugeli village under Bacheli Police Station limits in Dantewada District of Chhattisgarh, reports Ommcom News on June 4. Police team visited the village and had discussion with the residents, after receiving information about the fake CPI-Maoist activities in the area. Police team recovered two fake AK-47s, CPI-Maoist uniforms, and a bag hidden inside a hole. The AK-47s had been carved from wood and were being used by fake CPI-Maoist cadres to threaten the villagers. They used to enter the village during the night, kidnap wealthy people and collect ransom from their relatives. Unable to identify the weapons during the night, villagers also gave them money and other things. Police have launched a campaign to arrest them with the help of the villagers, said Dantewada Superintendent of Police (SP) Abhishek Pallav. **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Two teenage CPI-Maoist cadres have surrendered before the Security Forces (SFs) at Bhandaria Police Station of Garhwa District in Jharkhand on June 3, reports Dainik Jagran. Both these teenage CPI-Maoist cadres are 16 and 17 years old. One of them is **Read more...** Two teenage CPI-Maoist cadres have surrendered before the Security Forces (SFs) at Bhandaria Police Station of Garhwa District in Jharkhand on June 3, reports Dainik Jagran. Both these teenage CPI-Maoist cadres are 16 and 17 years old. One of them is from Karamdih Police Station limits of Latehar District and another is from Bhandaria Police Station limits in Garhwa District of Jharkhand. They were active members of Dalam (armed squad) of CPI-Maoist ‘commander’ Vimaji who carries a reward of INR 2.5 million for the past 18 months, said Superintendent of Police (SP) Srikant S Khotre **Read less...** | | June - 4 | Former Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) identified as Chhatradhar Mahato, the face of the CPI-Maoist backed tribal movement of 2008-11 in Lalgarh and presently a Trinamool Congress functionary moved the National Investigation Agency (NIA **Read more...** Former Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) identified as Chhatradhar Mahato, the face of the CPI-Maoist backed tribal movement of 2008-11 in Lalgarh and presently a Trinamool Congress functionary moved the National Investigation Agency (NIA) court on June 4 seeking house arrest, citing the Covid-19 situation and his failing health, reports Times of India on June 6. The former CPI-Maoist leader arrested in the 2009 Rajdhani Express hijack case has moved the NIA (NIA) court through a lawyer. On October 27, 2009, the Rajdhani Express was stopped at Banstala station in Jhargram District of West Bengal, adds Sangbad Pratidin **Read less...** | | June - 4 | Security Forces (SFs) recovered Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) weapons including two guns, a pistol, gelatin, electronic detonator, which were tied to plastic under the ground in Jamti forest under Bishanpur Police Station area of Guml **Read more...** Security Forces (SFs) recovered Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) weapons including two guns, a pistol, gelatin, electronic detonator, which were tied to plastic under the ground in Jamti forest under Bishanpur Police Station area of Gumla District of Jharkhand during a search operation, reports News 18 on June 5. A joint SFs team comprising of Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) 158 Battalion and District Police had information that CPI-Maoist ‘zonal commander’ Ravindra Ganju and his associates were active in the forest before the search operation. CPI-Maoist cadres have fled the location before the team of SFs had arrived to the location. **Read less...** | | June - 4 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadre identified as Madakam Nandal alias Nandu (20), a resident of Kourugutt village of Pameda Mandal (administrative sub-division) in Bijapur District of Chhattisgarh surrendered before the Police in Mulu **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadre identified as Madakam Nandal alias Nandu (20), a resident of Kourugutt village of Pameda Mandal (administrative sub-division) in Bijapur District of Chhattisgarh surrendered before the Police in Mulugu District of Telangana on June 4, reports Telangana Today. Nandu was working as a guard to the CPI-Maoist ‘commander’ of Special Guerilla Squad (SGS), Lachanna and he was suffering from ill-health and there was no chance of him getting proper treatment. He joined as a member of Cherla Arunakka Dalam (armed squad) in 2018 with the help of Somudu, an underground cadre, and worked there for one year as a Dalam member. On the instructions of Azad, Telangana State Committee member, he moved to Manuguru and worked as a guard to Lachanna. At the time of working as a guard to Lachanna, he participated in Battoom firing, Pedda Midisaleru road blasting and also in the exchange of fire at Tekulagudem of Chhattisgarh in which 24 Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) personnel died, said Superintendent of Police (SP), Mulugu, Dr Sangram Singh Ganpatrao Patil **Read less...** | | June - 4 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) have claimed that they killed a Police Constable identified as Manoj Netam who went missing on April 28 in Kanker District of Chhattisgarh, said Inspector General of Police (IGP), Bastar range, Sundarraj P **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) have claimed that they killed a Police Constable identified as Manoj Netam who went missing on April 28 in Kanker District of Chhattisgarh, said Inspector General of Police (IGP), Bastar range, Sundarraj P, reports The New Indian Express on June 5. title: Citizenship Amendment Act protests
full_text: # Citizenship Amendment Act protests - [Article](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests) - [Talk](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests) | | | --- | | It has been suggested that _[2024 Citizenship Amendment Act protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests)_ be [merged](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Merging) into this article. ( [Discuss](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#Merger_discussion))_Proposed since April 2024._ | | | | --- | | This article **may be [too long](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Article_size) to read and navigate comfortably**. When this tag was added, its [readable prose size](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:SIZERULE) was 14,500 words. Consider [splitting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Splitting) content into sub-articles, [condensing](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Summary_style) it, or adding [subheadings](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Section#Subsections). Please discuss this issue on the article's [talk page](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests)._(June 2024)_ | The **Citizenship Amendment Act (Bill) protests**, also known as the **CAA Protest**, **CAB Protest** or **CAA and NRC protests**,[\[74\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-74) occurred after the [Citizenship Amendment Act](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) (CAA) was enacted by the [Government of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_India) on 12 December 2019. The move sparked a widespread national and overseas ongoing protests against the act and its associated proposals of the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC).[\[75\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-hansindia-75) The protests first began in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and spread swiftly in other states such as[\[76\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-India_Today_12_Dec-76) Delhi,[\[77\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-77) [Meghalaya](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meghalaya),[\[78\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-78) [Arunachal Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh), and [Tripura](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripura) on 4 December 2019.[\[45\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-mamata_rally-45) Protests broke out rapidly across the country, although the concerns of the protesters vary.[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3)[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) | Citizenship Amendment Act protests | | --- | | [CAA](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) and [NRC](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) protests | | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/JMI_students_and_locals_protesting_against_CAA_NRC.jpg/600px-JMI_students_and_locals_protesting_against_CAA_NRC.jpg)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:JMI_students_and_locals_protesting_against_CAA_NRC.jpg) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Anti_CAA_protests_in_Guwahati.jpg/296px-Anti_CAA_protests_in_Guwahati.jpg)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Anti_CAA_protests_in_Guwahati.jpg) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Shaheen_Bagh_protestors_blocking_a_major_road_in_New_Delhi_for_28_days_Visual_taken_on_11_Jan_2020.jpg/296px-Shaheen_Bagh_protestors_blocking_a_major_road_in_New_Delhi_for_28_days_Visual_taken_on_11_Jan_2020.jpg)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Shaheen_Bagh_protestors_blocking_a_major_road_in_New_Delhi_for_28_days_Visual_taken_on_11_Jan_2020.jpg) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Locals_protest_against_CAB_CAA_%28cropped%29.jpg/296px-Locals_protest_against_CAB_CAA_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Locals_protest_against_CAB_CAA_(cropped).jpg) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Peoples_long_march_CAA_and_NRC_at_ernakulam%2C_kerala_9.jpg/296px-Peoples_long_march_CAA_and_NRC_at_ernakulam%2C_kerala_9.jpg)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Peoples_long_march_CAA_and_NRC_at_ernakulam,_kerala_9.jpg) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Muslim_Youth_League_CAA%2C_NRC_Protest_in_Kerala_2019.jpg/600px-Muslim_Youth_League_CAA%2C_NRC_Protest_in_Kerala_2019.jpg)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Muslim_Youth_League_CAA,_NRC_Protest_in_Kerala_2019.jpg) (Counterclockwise from top) [Jamia Milia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Milia_Islamia) students protesting, protests in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), Meghalaya, [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) and [Shaheen Bagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests) (New Delhi), protesters stopping traffic, [Aisa](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Students_Association) and [CPIML(L)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist-Leninist)_Liberation) protest in Kolkata. | | Date | 4 December 2019 (2019-12-04) – | | Location | [India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India) | | Caused by | - Introduction of [Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) - Anticipation of implementation of the [National Register of Citizens of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_of_India) - Police brutality against protesters[\[1\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-2) - [Violent crackdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_repression) against protesters[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3) | | Goals | - Repeal of the [Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) - Halt the implementation of the [National Register of Citizens of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_of_India) - Independent Judicial probe into various [Police departments](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_departments) for [police brutality](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_brutality)[\[4\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-5) - Resignation of [CM](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Uttar_Pradesh) [Yogi Adityanath](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi_Adityanath)[\[6\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-8) - Release of various [political prisoners](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_prisoners)[\[9\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-9)[\[10\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-10)[\[11\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-11) | | Methods | **Protesters:** [Civil disobedience](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_disobedience), [demonstrations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demonstration_(political)), _[Dharna](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharna)_, _[Gherao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gherao)_, [hunger strikes](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_strikes), _[Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha)_, _[Hartal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartal)_, [vandalism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandalism), _[arson](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arson)_, [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting), [hashtag activism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hashtag_activism), [general strike](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_strike) _( [Bandh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandh))_, Shooting **Government and supporters:** [Mass shooting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_shooting) by police, [Riot police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riot_police), [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting), [vandalism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandalism), [_lathi charge_](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baton_charge), [Mass arrest](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_arrest), [Internet shutdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_shutdown), [curfew](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curfew), transport restrictions, [water cannon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_cannon), imposing ban on assembly ( [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144)) | | Status | **Stopped**. It became indispensable to stop due to the [lockdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lockdown) being imposed in the country to curb the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India)[\[12\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-12) **Previously:** - [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144), [curfew](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curfew), [Internet shutdown](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_shutdown) imposed in various parts of the country. - [Indian Army](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Army) deployed in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam). - [Paramilitary forces](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramilitary_forces_of_India) deployed in various parts of the country. | | Parties | | | | | | --- | --- | | [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Emblem_of_India.svg/40px-Emblem_of_India.svg.png)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Emblem_of_India.svg)**[Government of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_India)** - 3000+[\[73\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_17Dec-73) (reported as of 17 December) | The CAA amends the Indian citizenship act to provide accelerated pathway for citizenship for illegal migrants who are [Hindu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus), [Sikh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs), [Jain](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jain), [Parsi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsis), [Buddhist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist), and [Christian](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christians) from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan, and who entered India before 2014, following the [religious persecutions](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_persecution).[\[80\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_explained-80) The bill reduced the time taken for naturalization for this category from twelve years to six years. The bill does not mention [Muslims](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslims) and other communities who fled from the same or other neighbouring countries. Refugees from [Sri Lankan Tamils in India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Tamils_in_India), [Rohingyas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya) from [Myanmar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar), and [Tibetan refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tibetan_refugees_in_India) are also not mentioned in the bill.[\[81\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IEConception-81)[\[82\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-82) The proposed [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC) will be an official record of all legal citizens of India. Individuals would need to provide a prescribed set of documents before a specified cutoff date to be included in it.[\[83\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-83) The amendment has been widely criticised as [discriminating on the basis of religion](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_discrimination), particularity for excluding Muslims.[\[84\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NPRExcludes-84) Protestors against the amendment demand that it be scrapped and that the nationwide NRC not be implemented.[\[85\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-wsjdelhi-85)[\[86\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sigal_Samuel-86)[\[87\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-87) The bill has raised concerns among the Indian Muslim community.[\[88\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-88)[\[89\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-89)[\[90\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-90)[\[91\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-91) They are also concerned that all citizens will be affected by the bureaucratic exercise of the NRC where they will have to prove their citizenship for inclusion in the registry.[\[92\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-92)[\[93\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-93) The protesters have raised voices against authoritarianism and the police crackdown in universities to suppress protests.[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3)[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) Protesters in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and other [northeastern states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India) do not want [Indian citizenship](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_citizenship) to be granted to any refugee or immigrant, regardless of their religion, as they fear it would alter the region's demographic balance, resulting in a loss of their political rights, culture, and land.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) They are also concerned that it will motivate further [migration](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_migration) from [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) that could violate the [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord) which was a prior agreement reached with the central government on migrants and refugees.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) The protests started in Assam on 4 December 2019, after the bill was introduced in parliament. Later on, protests erupted in [Northeast India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India), and subsequently spread to the major cities of India. On 15 December, major protests took place near [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) in New Delhi and [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University). As the protests broke out, mobs burnt and destroyed public as well as private properties and several railway stations were vandalised.[\[98\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-98)[\[99\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-99)[\[100\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-100) Police [forcibly entered](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jamia_Milia_Islamia_attack) the campus of Jamia, used batons and [tear gas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tear_gas) on the students, and more than 200 students were injured while around 100 were detained overnight in the police station. The police action was widely criticised and resulted students across the country protesting in solidarity.[\[101\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-101)[\[102\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-102) The protests resulted in thousands of arrests and 27 deaths as of 27 December 2019.[\[103\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_arrests-103)[\[67\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_27_Dead-67) Two 17-year-old minors were among those reported to have been killed due to police firing during a live ammunition on protesters in Assam.[\[104\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minors-104) On 19 December, the police issued a complete ban on protests in several parts of India. As a result of defying the ban, thousands of protesters were detained.[\[105\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-105) ## Contents - [1Background](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#Background) - [12See also](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#See_also) - [13References](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#References) - [14External links](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#External_links) ## Background [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=1) A child taking part in an anti-CAB NRC protest with [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) students and locals. ### Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=2) Main article: [Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_(Amendment)_Act,_2019) [The Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, 2019](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Citizenship_(Amendment)_Bill,_2019) (CAB) was introduced by the Home Minister, [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah) on the floor of the Parliament of India on 9 December 2019 in response to the exclusion of 1.9 million people, predominantly Hindus and Muslims[\[106\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-106) in the [National Register of Citizens for Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_for_Assam).[\[107\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-107) The Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 (CAA) was passed by the [Parliament of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_India) on 11 December. It amends the [Citizenship Act of 1955](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_nationality_law) to grant a swifter path to Indian citizenship under the assumption of [religious persecution](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_persecution) to any individual belonging to the specific minorities of [Hindus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus), [Sikhs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs), [Buddhists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist), [Jains](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jain), [Parsis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsis) and Christians from [Afghanistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan), [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) and [Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan), who entered India on or before 31 December 2014.[\[108\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-108) The Act also seeks to relax the requirement of residence in India for citizenship by [naturalisation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalisation) from 11 years to 5 years for migrants covered under the Act.[\[109\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-109) However, the Act does not mention Muslims and does not offer the same eligibility benefits to Muslim immigrants or immigrants belonging to other religions from those countries.[\[110\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Samuel-110) The Act also does not mention any benefits for various other refugees which form the bulk of the refugees living in India, such as [Sri Lankan Tamil refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Tamils_in_India) who faced persecution during the [Sri Lankan Civil War](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Civil_War),[\[111\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-111) [Rohingya refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya_Refugee_Crisis) who were victims of the [Rohingya genocide](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya_genocide), [Nepali refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutanese_refugees) who faced [ethnic cleansing in Bhutan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing_in_Bhutan), and [Tibetan Buddhist refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tibetan_refugees_in_India) who faced persecution in China.[\[112\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-WPCitizenship22-112) According to the [Intelligence Bureau](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence_Bureau_(India)), the immediate beneficiaries of the new law will be 25,447 Hindus, 5,807 Sikhs, 55 Christians, 2 Buddhists and 2 Parsis.[\[113\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-angry22-113) ### Response [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=3) The passage of the Act sparked massive protests in India.[\[110\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Samuel-110) Protesters in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and other [northeastern states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India) oppose the grant of [Indian citizenship](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_citizenship) to any refugee or immigrant, regardless of their religion, because they fear it would alter the region's demographic balance. They have campaigned since the 1970s against all refugees, and they fear that the new law will cause a loss of their political rights, culture and land.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) They are also concerned that it will trigger more migration from [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) as well as violate the [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord), which was a prior agreement reached with the central government on migrants and refugees.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) After the act was passed, protests in the northeastern region turned violent. Authorities had arrested over 3000 protesters as of 17 December 2019,[\[73\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_17Dec-73) and some news outlets have described these protests as [riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riots).[\[114\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-114) Protesters say that the Act violates Clause 5 and Clause 6 of the 1985 [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord).[\[115\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-115) Critics have stated that the amendment Act is unconstitutional.[\[116\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-116)[\[117\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-guardian-117)[\[118\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-118) The major opposition political parties state that it violates Constitution's Article 14, one that guarantees equality to all. They allege that the new law seeks to make Muslims second-class citizens of India, while preferentially treating non-Muslims in India.[\[119\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-119) Critics of the Act have also stated that due to the [National Register of Citizens (NRC)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_of_India), Muslims could be made [stateless](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statelessness), while the Citizenship Amendment Act would be able to shield people with Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi or Christian identity as a means of providing them with Indian citizenship even if they fail to prove that they were citizens of India under the stringent requirements of the NRC. Some critics allege that it is a deliberate attempt at [disenfranchising](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disfranchisement) and segregating Muslims in line with the [ethnonationalist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnonationalist) [Hindutva](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindutva) ideology of the ruling [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) (BJP).[\[120\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-120)[\[81\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IEConception-81)[\[121\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AsianAgeOrwellian-121) [Tavleen Singh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tavleen_Singh) described the Act as India's first [Nuremberg Law](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuremberg_Laws).[\[122\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-122) The home minister [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah) had previously set a deadline for the implementation of a countrywide NRC by stating that the register would be rolled out before the [2024 Lok Sabha elections](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Indian_general_election).[\[123\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-livemint_NRC-123) The Act was criticised by various NGOs, students bodies, and liberal, progressive, and socialist organisations across the country, with the [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) and other major political parties announcing their staunch opposition. Protests led by these groups are concerned that the new law discriminates against Muslims, and believe that Indian citizenship should also be granted to Muslim refugees and immigrants. The states of [Rajasthan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajasthan), West Bengal, [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala), Maharashtra, [Madhya Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh), Jharkhand[\[124\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-124) and [Chhattisgarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chhattisgarh) – all ruled by political parties that oppose the BJP – have announced that they will not implement either the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC) or the Citizenship Amendment Act. The states of [Bihar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar), Andhra Pradesh and [Odisha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odisha) have however refused to only implement the NRC, while the state of [Punjab](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab,_India) and the union territories of Delhi and [Puducherry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory)) have refused to implement the Act while only expressing disapproval of the NRC.[\[125\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-125)[\[126\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-126)[\[127\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-127) The states of [West Bengal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Bengal) and [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) have also put a hold on all activities relating to the preparation and update of the [National Population Register](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Population_Register) which is necessary for the Census as well as the implementation of the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens).[\[128\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-128) Although some of the states have opposed the Act, the [Union Home Ministry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) clarified that states lack the legal power to stop the implementation of CAA. The Ministry stated that "The new legislation has been enacted under the Union List of the 7th Schedule of the Constitution. The states have no power to reject it."[\[129\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_MP_19_Dec-129) The [Indian Union Muslim League](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Union_Muslim_League) and various other bodies have also petitioned the [Supreme Court of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) to strike down the Act as illegal and unconstitutional.[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) ## Chronology [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=4) ### December 2019 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=5) - **4 December** - The Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, 2019 was cleared by the [Union Cabinet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Council_of_Ministers) for introduction in the parliament.[\[131\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-131) - After the bill was cleared, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) - In [Dispur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispur), several thousands of protesters broke down police barricades to protest in front of the [Assam Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Legislative_Assembly) building.[\[133\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-133)[\[134\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-New_York_Times-134) - Demonstrations were held in [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[135\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-135) Six people died and fifty people were injured in the protests against the Act.[\[136\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-136)[\[137\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_16_Dec-137) - **9 December** - The bill was introduced in the [Lok Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha) by the Minister of Home Affairs, [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah).[\[138\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-138) - **10 December** - The bill was passed with 311 members voting in favour and 80 against.[\[139\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-139)[\[140\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-140) - **11 December** - The bill was subsequently passed by the [Rajya Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajya_Sabha) with 125 votes in favour and 105 votes against it. Those parties that had voted in favour include BJP allies such as the [Janata Dal (United)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)) and the [AIADMK](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Anna_Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam) and non-aligned parties such as the [Biju Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biju_Janata_Dal).[\[141\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_RS_Passed-141) - **12 December** - After receiving assent from the [President of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India), the bill assumed the status of an act.[\[142\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-assent-142) The act would come into force on 10 January, chosen by the Government of India, and would be notified as such.[\[143\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-gazette-143)[\[144\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_in_force_10_Jan-144) - Dipanjal Das and Sam Stafford were killed in police firing during a protest in Guwahati.[\[145\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto3-145) - [Akhil Gogoi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Gogoi) was taken in preventive custody.[\[146\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAkhil19-146) A poster at Shaheen Bagh protests New Delhi - **13 December** - UK, US, France, Israel and Canada issued [travel warnings](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_warning) for their citizens visiting India's north-east region, where the protests were mainly taking place, asking them to "exercise caution".[\[147\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-147) - The Chief Ministers of the Indian states of West Bengal, Punjab, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh had stated that they would not implement the act.[\[148\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-148) - **14 December** - Ishwar Nayak was killed in police firing at a protest in Assam.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) - Thousands of people protested against the law at the [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar,_New_Delhi) in New Delhi.[\[150\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_Jantar-150)[\[151\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Jantar-151) - **15 December** - In Assam, Abdul Alim, a protester, died due to police firing in a protest the previous day.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149)[\[152\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-152) - In Jamia Nagar, Delhi, three [Delhi Transport Corporation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Transport_Corporation) buses were torched as protests took a violent turn.[\[153\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:5-153) - A group of artists in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati,_Assam) staged a concert in protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act 2019.[\[154\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-154) - Police forcefully entered the campus of [Jamia Milia Islamia university](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) and detained students. According to video footage, the police used batons and tear gas on the students. More than two hundred students were injured and around a hundred were detained. The police action was widely criticised, and resulted in protests across the country and abroad.[\[155\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters16Dec-155) There were also allegations that the police attacked students who were not part of the protests.[\[156\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-156) - Protests were held outside the campus of the [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University). In the evening, police officers forcefully entered the campus and attacked students. At least 80 students were injured in the attacks.[\[157\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Aligarh-157)[\[158\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-158) - In West Bengal, violent protests occurred and five trains were set on fire by protesters in [Lalgola](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lalgola_railway_station) and [Krishnapur railway stations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnapur_railway_station) in [Murshidabad district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad_district).[\[159\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_14Dec-159) - **16 December** - In Lucknow, police prevented around 300 students of [Nadwa University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadwa_University) from staging a peaceful protest outside the campus; clashes ensued later.[\[160\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_Nadwa-160) Around 15 to 20 students were injured and around 30 students were charged by the police for attempt to murder and violence.[\[161\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Exp_Nadwa_17_Dec-161) - [Priyanka Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priyanka_Gandhi) led a silent protest at the [India Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_Gate) along with about three hundred [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) workers to show solidarity with the students of Jamia Milia Islamia after the previous day's incidents.[\[49\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Priyanka_Gandhi-49) - A [Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha) was organised by the [All Assam Students' Union](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) across [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam), which would continue till 18 December.[\[162\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAASU-162) - In West Bengal thousands of people joined a demonstration led by Chief Minister [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and her ruling [Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) party.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) - Prime Minister [Narendra Modi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi) appealed for calm on Twitter and clarified that CAA was for immigrants.[\[137\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_16_Dec-137)[\[163\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-163)\[ _[non-primary source needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources)_\] - **17 December** - Violent clashes occurred in Delhi's [Seelampur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seelampur_subdivision) area. Police retaliated with tear gas and batons against the stone throwing protesters. Several protesters and officers were injured. A police station was set on fire and buses were vandalised in the area.[\[164\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc_Seelampur-164) - A dawn-to-dusk hartal (shutdown) was observed in Kerala by the [Welfare Party of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_Party_of_India), [Bahujan Samaj Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahujan_Samaj_Party), [Social Democratic Party of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_India) and 30 other organisations against the Citizenship Amendment Act and the police violence against students at various universities across the country, in relation to anti-CAA protests.[\[165\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITStoned-165)[\[166\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TimesNowKeralaHartal-166) - **18 December** - The [Supreme Court of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) heard 60 petitions challenging the Act and declined to stay implementation of CAA. 22 January 2020 was set as the next date of hearing on the constitutional validity of the act.[\[167\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-167) - A statement "condemning the recent police action and brutalisation of students at Jamia Millia University and Aligarh Muslim University" was signed by signatories from more than 1,100 academic institutions across the world.[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) - **19 December** - 3 protesters (2 in [Mangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mangalore) and 1 in [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow)) were killed in police firing.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168) - Various administrative authorities imposed bans against public gatherings, especially in [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) ruled states such as [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka), Uttar Pradesh and parts of Delhi, where the police comes under the BJP-ruled central government.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169)[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) Access to [mobile-based internet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_broadband) was shut down in certain places in Delhi and Bangalore.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) - Internet was suspended in certain regions of Uttar Pradesh including the state capital, [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow) where data and text services were restricted till noon of 21 December 2019. Internet services were also suspended in Sambhal, Aligarh, Mau, Ghaziabad, and Azamgarh districts, as well as [Dakshina Kannada](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dakshina_Kannada) district in Karnataka.[\[171\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-171) - Protest meetings were held defying bans in Delhi's [Red Fort](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Fort) and Bengaluru.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) Tens of thousands of people protested in Hyderabad, Patna, Chandigarh, Mumbai and other cities. Calls were made on social media platforms asking people to turn up and protest peacefully.[\[172\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_19_Dec-172) - In Delhi, politicians [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav) and [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury) along with around 1,200 protesters were detained by the police.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169)[\[173\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-173) - In Delhi, at least 700 flights were delayed and more than 20 cancelled due to traffic jams caused by police closing roads to stop protests.[\[174\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Flights-174) - In Bengaluru, historian [Ramchandra Guha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramchandra_Guha) along with several other professors were detained by the police. According to the police, around 200 protesters had been detained in Bengaluru.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) - Curfew was imposed in [Mangaluru](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mangaluru) until 20 December, after violent clashes and the death of 2 people due to police firing.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170)[\[175\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ToIMalayali19-175) The police later allegedly forced its way into the hospital where the 2 victims were brought.[\[176\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto2-176)[\[177\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto1-177) - UNICEF issued a statement asking the government to respect children's right of freedom of expression, peaceful assembly and protest as per the [Convention on the Rights of the Child](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convention_on_the_Rights_of_the_Child).[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) - In [Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad), during a violent clash in the [Shah-e-Alam's Roza](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shah-e-Alam%27s_Roza) area police used tear gas to defend themselves and counter [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting) while trying to disperse a crowd of around 2000 protesters.[\[178\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_Gujarat_19-178) - 90 protesters including 50 students of the [Hyderabad university](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad_university) were detained by [Hyderabad police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad_police).[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) - A crowd consisting of thousands of protesters gathered at [Moulali](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moulali) in central [Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata) to peacefully protest against CAA and NRC.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) - Protests involving 20,000 protesters concluded peacefully at the [August Kranti Maidan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Kranti_Maidan) at Mumbai.[\[179\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Mumbai_Mirror_19-179) - **20 December** - 6 protesters (one each in [Meerut](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meerut), [Sambhal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sambhal), [Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanpur) and [Firozabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firozabad) and 2 in [Bijnor](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bijnor)) were killed in separate police firing incidents in UP.[\[180\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_6_deaths_in_up-180) - [Bhim Army](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhim_Army) Chief [Chandrashekhar Azad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandrashekhar_Azad_Ravan) conducted a protest march at the [Jama Masjid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jama_Masjid,_Delhi) in Delhi.[\[181\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Bhim-181) - **21 December** - Chandrashekhar Azad was arrested along with 27 people and three FIRs were registered for certain violent incidents on 20 December at [Delhi Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Gate,_Delhi) and Seemapuri.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) - 1100 academics and academia staff from around the world issued a joint statement supporting the act.[\[183\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-183) - Peaceful protests were conducted in West Bengal, Assam, Meghalaya, Maharashtra and Delhi.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) An all-woman protest was organised across Assam.[\[184\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ReutersHundreds-184) - A spontaneous protest march, approximately 1.5 km long occurred in Kolkata.[\[185\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TelegraphFloodgates-185) - Clashes were reported during protests near [Chennai Central railway station](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai_Central_railway_station).[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) - 1 protester dies and several are injured in clashes at multiple locations in Uttar Pradesh. Access to the internet is still restricted at many places.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) - In Patna and other towns of Bihar, supporters of the [Rashtriya Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Janata_Dal) (RJD) protested at bus and train stations and blocked roads.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) - An 18-year-old protester, Amir Hanzla was beaten to death by [Hindu extremists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saffron_terror) for his role in the protests.[\[186\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-186)[\[187\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-187) - **22 December** - The [Chief Minister of Rajasthan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Rajasthan), [Ashok Gehlot](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashok_Gehlot) held a protest march termed the " [Samvidhan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India) Bachao Rally" which was attended by around 300,000 people.[\[188\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITRajasthan-188) - The Karnataka government announced an ex-gratia compensation of [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)10 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$12,000) each to the families of the two men killed in violent protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act in Mangaluru on 19 December.[\[189\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_Kar_10_Lakh-189) However, the compensation was withheld on 26 December, impending an enquiry on the killed men.[\[190\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IE_26_Dec_Karnataka-190) - The Uttar Pradesh government created a panel to assess the damage to the property and to recover the losses by seizing the property of the alleged protesters.[\[191\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Lucknow_22_Dec_IT-191) - **23 December** - Protests involving 80,000 protesters concluded peacefully in Bangalore.[\[192\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ToI_80000-192) - Dibrugarh police arrested 55 people for involvement in acts of violence in the district during protests against the Amendment.[\[193\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-193) - Unidentified people assaulted three migrant labourers from West Bengal for allegedly taking part in anti-CAA protests.[\[194\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-194) - An FIR was registered against [AAP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aam_Aadmi_Party) MLA [Amanatullah Khan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amanatullah_Khan) over charges of "sharing an objectionable post" on the social media against the act.[\[195\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-195) - 31 people were arrested for violence during an anti-CAA protest in [Rampur, Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rampur,_Uttar_Pradesh).[\[196\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-196) - **24 December** - Despite widespread ongoing protests, the central government approved the updation of the [National Population Register](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Population_Register) (NPR) and allocated [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)3,941.35 [crore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crore) (US$470 million) for it.[\[197\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_24_dec-197) - A German exchange student at [IIT Madras](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IIT_Madras) was deported by the Indian authorities for participating in the CAA protests.[\[198\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AP_German-198)[\[199\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-German_Express-199) - Reports of [police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh_Police) vandalising homes, shops and cars and accusing and arresting protesters of taking part in vandalism emerged from various parts of the state of [Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh).[\[200\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Muzaffarnagar-200)[\[201\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SiasatRakshak-201)[\[202\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTVVandalising-202) - 1,000-1,200 protesters were booked for organising a candle march in [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University) for violating Section 144.[\[203\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto7-203) - **26 December** - In [Sambhal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sambhal), UP, the government sent notices to 26 people for their alleged involvement in damaging properties during protests and asked them to explain their position or pay for the loss due to damage of property. The losses to the property were assessed to be [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)11.66 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$14,000).[\[204\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sambhal_Damage-204) - **27 December** - 357 people including 75 women protesting against CAA and police atrocities were detained by the Delhi police near the UP Bhavan.[\[205\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_28_Dec_UP-205) - **28 December** - The [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress), on its foundation day, undertook a flag march in Mumbai and coined the slogan "Save Bharat-Save Constitution".[\[206\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Express_live_28_Dec-206) Similar marches were held in many parts of the country.[\[207\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Congress_28_Dec_N18-207) - In [Meerut](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meerut), U.P. government demanded ₹25,000 (US$300) each from more than 140 people, a total of [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)40 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$48,000) as penalty for damages caused during protests on 20 December.[\[208\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Express_28_Dec_UP-208) - **29 December** - The [Shaheen Bagh protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests), which started on 15 December and were participated in mainly by house wives and old women with their children,[\[209\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-209)[\[210\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-210)[\[211\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-211) gathered mainstream media attention on 29 December. Despite Delhi experiencing the second coldest night in the last 100 years,[\[212\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-212)[\[213\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-213) the women protesters sat on an indefinite protest at Shaheen Bagh, .[\[214\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-214)[\[215\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-215)[\[216\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-216) [Shaheen Bagh protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests) on 4 January 2020. Protesters are still gathered blocking a major New Delhi road for over three weeks.[\[217\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-217) (Bottom) Huge anti-CAA NRC banners across a footbridge at Shaheen Bagh. - LGBT Rights activists protested against the CAA and NRC at the [Kolkata Pride Parade](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata_Rainbow_Pride_Walk).[\[218\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-218)[\[219\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-219) - **30 December** - Delhi Police arrested street vendors, accusing them of stone pelting and inciting violence during the Jamia Milia Islamia attacks.[\[220\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-220)[\[221\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-221) - **31 December** - Protests were held during New Year's Eve celebrations in Delhi,[\[222\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-222) Hyderabad,[\[223\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-223) [Bhubaneshwar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhubaneshwar),[\[224\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-224) Mumbai and Kolkata.[\[225\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-225)[\[226\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-226) ### January 2020 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=6) -
