**1 January** - About 50,000–170,000[\[227\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-227) people participated in an anti-CAA rally organised by Muslim organisations[\[228\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-228) in [Kochi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kochi).[\[229\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-229)[\[230\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-230) The numbers swelled to 500,000,[\[231\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-231) the unusually large size of the protest causing a complete standstill of traffic throughout the city.[\[232\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-232) - **3 January** - The UP Police admitted that it had wrongfully accused and arrested poor innocent people; and releases four minors from jail due to lack of evidence.[\[233\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-233)[\[234\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-234) - **4 January** - More than 100,000 protesters attended a protest march named "Million March" against the Citizenship Amendment Bill held in Hyderabad.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) - In Bangalore hundreds of protesters participated in a rally and accused the [Modi government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modi_government) of attempting to divide India on the basis of religion, and distracting people from the issues of economic slowdown and unemployment in the country.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) - **5 January** - A masked mob, allegedly composed of [Hindu extremists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saffron_terror) from the [Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Bharatiya_Vidyarthi_Parishad), armed with rods and sticks attacked the campus of [Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University,_Delhi) and injured more than 40 students and teachers.[\[236\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Masked_JNU-236) The attack was described as an attempt to suppress [student activism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_activism) during the Citizenship Amendment Act protests.[\[237\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-237) - **6 January** - 50,000 women held an "all women's rally" in [Malegaon](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malegaon), Maharashtra.[\[238\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:2-238) - **7 January** - Women in Kolkata started a sit-in protest at the grounds of Park Circus in Kolkata.[\[239\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Park_Circus_16_Jan-239) - **8 January** - PM Modi cancelled his visit to Assam, while the CAA protests continue. AASU had planned huge protests during Modi's visit.[\[240\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Modi_8_Jan-240)[\[241\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_8_Jan-241) - Thousands of people joined the anti-CAA protests at Dibrugarh, Guwahati and other parts of Assam.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242)[\[243\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-nenow_8_January_2020-243) - **9 January** - Students of JNU attempted to march towards [Rashtrapati Bhavan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtrapati_Bhavan), the official residence of the [President of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India) while blocking [Janpath](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janpath). Police detained around 100 students when the march was blocking Janpath.[\[244\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-244) - The Chief Justice of India dismissed a petition by a lawyer demanding that the CAA be declared constitutionally valid, stating that "There is anyway a presumption of constitutionality".[\[245\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-245) - Asom Jatiyatabadi Yuba Chatra Parishad (AJYCP) along with All Assam Students’ Union (AASU), the Krishak Mukti Sangram Samiti (KMSS) and 30 other organisations and artist communities organised protests against CAA in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati). They demanded "corruption-free, foreigner-free, terrorism-free and pollution-free Assam" from the Chief Minister of Assam, [Sarbananda Sonowal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarbananda_Sonowal) rather than implementing CAA-NRC.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242) - **10 January** - The Citizenship Amendment Act came into force.[\[144\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_in_force_10_Jan-144) - The [Delhi High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_High_Court) dismissed a plea to remove the [protesters occupying Shaheen Bagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests).[\[246\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Delhi_HC_10_Jan-246) - **11 January** - PM Modi visited Kolkata on a two day official visit. Hundreds of people protested against CAA at the Kolkata airport.[\[247\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rediff_11_Jan-247) - Several parties and student unions launched a protest at the Dorina Crossing at Esplanade in Kolkata. SFI leader stated that the protests would continue till Sunday, until PM Modi (who had been visiting the city) was in Kolkata.[\[248\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_11_Jan-248) - A " [Tiranga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_India) Rally" against the CAA was held in Hyderabad, with thousands[\[249\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-249) of people displaying the national flag.[\[250\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-250) Police officers were seen [caning](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caning) peaceful protesters.[\[251\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-251) - [Pradyot Manikya Debbarma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirit_Pradyot_Deb_Barman), the royal scion of the [Manikya dynasty](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manikya_dynasty), led the largest protest in Tripura as of 11 January 2020 consisting of thousands of people.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) Debbarma stated that beneficiaries of CAA will not be allowed to settle in Tripura. He added that the state has already accommodated many migrants from [East Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Pakistan) and further immigration due to CAA will endanger the threatened indigenous residents of Tripura.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) - **12 January** - In Kolkata, the protesters outside the venue of PM Modi's speech were detained by the police.[\[253\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Ramakrishna_12_Jan-253) - Thousands of people join the anti CAA protests at Jogeshwari in Mumbai. Slogans such as "I Am From Gujarat, My Documents Burned in 2002", "No CAA, Boycott NRC, Stop Dividing India, Don't Divide us", "Save Constitution", were displayed on the banners.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) - The Indian National Congress demanded the withdrawal of CAA, and stopping of the process to update NPR. It claimed that the NPR was a 'disguised NRC'.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) - **13 January** - The [Parliamentary panel on Home Affairs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Indian_parliamentary_committees#Department-related_standing_committees) criticised the Delhi Police for the violent crackdown on Jamia and JNU and asked them not to be harsh.[\[255\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_CAA_13_Jan-255) - A meeting of 20 opposition parties in Delhi released a statement demanding a revocation of the CAA and asked all the Chief Ministers who have refused to implement the NRC in their states to stop the work of updating the [National Population Register](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Population_Register), as it is the foundation of NRC.[\[256\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Stop_NPR_13_Jan-256)[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) - At Jamia Millia Islamia, several student groups protested outside the office of Vice-Chancellor Najma Akhtar asking to reschedule the exam dates, filing a case against Delhi Police and ensuring the safety of students. The VC announced in the afternoon, that a case will be filed against police on 14 January.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) - **14 January** - The [Kerala government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_government) approached the Supreme Court to challenge the CAA under Section 131 of the Constitution and became the first state to do so.[\[257\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kerala_CAA_14_Jan-257)[\[258\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-14_Jan-258) - [Mani Shankar Aiyar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mani_Shankar_Aiyar) of the Indian National Congress joined the anti CAA protesters at Shaheen Bagh.[\[259\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Live14_Jan-259) - 5000 women staged a sit-in protest at Mansoor Ali park in [Prayagraj](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prayagraj), Uttar Pradesh.[\[260\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Live_14_Jan-260) - In Mumbai, a group of students attended the India v/s Australia match at Wankhede stadium and peacefully protested by wearing T-shirts with the message "No NPR, NO NRC and NO CAA".[\[260\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Live_14_Jan-260) - In Gujarat, people celebrated [Makar Sankranti](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Makar_Sankranti) by flying kites with slogans for and against CAA.[\[261\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-261) - **15 January** - More than 200,000 people joined the Anti-CAA protests in Mangalore, where hundreds of people came in boats carrying Indian flags. Activists Harsh Mander and former [IAS officer](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IAS_officer) Kannan Gopinathan gave speeches during the protests. The protests ended peacefully with the singing of National anthem.[\[262\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Mangalore_15_Jan-262) - Women conducted sit-in protests at Patna's [Sabzibagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sabzibagh&action=edit&redlink=1) and Kolkata's [Park Circus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Park_Circus), Allahabad's Roshan Bagh, Kanpur's [Chaman Ganj](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaman_Ganj,_Kanpur), Gaya's Shanti Bagh along with Delhi's Shaheen Bagh.[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263)[\[264\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-264) - A petition was filed in Gujarat High court asking its intervention to allow citizens to hold Anti-CAA protests in Ahmedabad. The petitioners stated that the Gujarat Police did not grant them permission for peaceful protests but granted permission to 62 programmes held by the ruling BJP to support the CAA. The court asked the police to decide properly on the protesters' applications.[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) - A Delhi court granted bail and released Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad aka "Raavan", who had been arrested for his protest in December against CAA at [Jama Masjid, Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jama_Masjid,_Delhi).[\[265\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Azad_bail_15_Jan-265) - Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) postpones all exams due to the ongoing CAA protests.[\[266\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AMU_postpones_exams_15_Jan-266) - **16 January** - Police in [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai) banned all protests in the city for a period of 15 days. Five women and one man (including a physically disabled person) were detained by the police for protesting against CAA.[\[267\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNM_Chennai_16_Jan-267) - **17 January** - Inspired by the Shaheen Bagh protest, a massive anti-CAA-NRC-NPR protest was started in Mumbai. Around 10,000 women gathered at the YMCA ground in Mumbai to protest in the evening. The protest was organised by a Non-governmental organisation named Mumbai Citizen Quorum.[\[268\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shaheen_Mumbai-268)[\[269\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-269) - Around 500 women began a sit-in protest at the Clock tower grounds in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270) - **18 January** - Uttar Pradesh police cracked down on the CAA protesters demonstrating near the Clock Tower in [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow) and snatched their personal belongings.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) - **19 January** - In Delhi, hundreds of protesters joined a protest march holding lighted candles from Jamia University to Shaheen Bagh.[\[272\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Delhi_candle-272) - In [Berlin](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berlin), Germany more than 200 people join the protest march against CAA, NRC and the [JNU attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_JNU_attack). The march was led by the Indian diaspora and started at the [Brandenburg Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate) and ended at the Indian Embassy.[\[273\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Germany_19_Jan-273) - An all women protest started on 11 January, outside Konark Mall in [Pune](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pune), organised by Kul Jamaat-e-Tanzeem, an umbrella body of several organisations, reached its ninth day with around 500–600 protesters participating all throughout the day.[\[274\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Pune_Shaheen-274) - **20 January** - Several [Labour Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)) [MPs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_of_parliament) of the [Uk parliament](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uk_parliament) discussed concerns regarding the CAA, in a meeting organised by South Asia Solidarity Group (SASG) and Ambedkar International Mission (UK) in London.[\[275\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Labour_MP_21_Jan-275) The MPs expressed concern on its implications on human rights and disenfranchisement of the Muslim community.[\[276\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-newsclick_labour_UK-276) - **21 January** - More than 300,000 people join an anti-CAA protest rally at [Kalaburagi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalaburagi) in Karnataka.[\[277\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kalburgi_22_Jan-277) - In UP's Etawah, a video emerged that showed Police chasing and attacking the women protesters with batons in their attempts to break the protest.[\[278\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_Etawah_stick-278) - In a unique way of protesting, more than a hundred women protesters at Khureji Khas in Delhi released 10,000 gas filled black coloured balloons with the message "No CAA NPR NRC".[\[279\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-10K_quint-279)[\[280\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-10000_balloons-280) - Police register cases against 160 women for violation of the ban on assembly and protesting against CAA in Lucknow.[\[281\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-160_booked_21_Jan-281) - Despite ban on assembly, Home Minister Amit Shah was allowed by the administration to address a pro CAA public rally at Lucknow.[\[281\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-160_booked_21_Jan-281) Amit Shah said that the protesters could continue protesting but the government would not revoke the CAA.[\[282\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Amit_Shah_Lucknow_21_Jan-282) - Various college students' associations had called a complete shutdown of colleges and universities in the north-east on 22 Jan, asking the Supreme Court to declare CAA as unconstitutional.[\[283\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_NE_strike_21_Jan-283) - **22 January** - Thousands of students from 9 universities in North-East India boycott classes and join protest march in the states of [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam), Nagaland, [Meghalaya](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meghalaya) and [Arunachal Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh).[\[284\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_22_Jan_Assam-284)[\[285\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Assam_CAA_22_Jan-285)[\[286\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_NDTV_NE-286) - A 5 kilometre long procession against CAA was led by CM [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) in [Darjeeling](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darjeeling), West Bengal.[\[287\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_Darjeeling-287) - Women continued sit-in protests for the third day at the Haj House near Kadru Over Bridge in [Ranchi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranchi), Jharkhand.[\[288\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Ranchi_23_Jan-288) - 144 CAA related petitions scheduled for hearing in the Supreme Court of India were brought up. [Chief Justice of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_India) [Sharad A. Bobde](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharad_A._Bobde) had led the three-judge bench.[\[289\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-144_petitions_21_Jan-289) The court gave notice to the government on the petitions and allowed one month to respond in the next hearing in February.[\[290\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SC_refuses_22_Jan-290) The Supreme Court also segregated the case of Assam and Tripura considering the fact of cross-border infiltration and assured of looking into the matter separately.[\[291\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-291) - A fact-finding team consisting of students of various prominent universities like [Banaras Hindu University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banaras_Hindu_University), [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) and [JNU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University) released a report after visiting 15 violence-affected cities in Uttar Pradesh and accused the Uttar Pradesh police of brutality in dealing with protesters and attacking Muslims. The police was accused of violating basic principles of fire arms usage by firing above the waist.[\[292\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-23_Jan_Student_fact-292) - While addressing a Pro-CAA public meeting in Lucknow the CM of UP threatened to charge the protesters with [sedition](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedition) if they raised slogans demanding _Azadi_ (Freedom) in Uttar Pradesh.[\[293\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Azadi_slogan_UP_22_Jan-293) - **24 January** - A statewide shutdown, "Maharashtra Bandh" was organised by Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) across [Maharashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maharashtra) state, to protest against the CAA and the economic policies of the BJP-led central government, which according to the organisers "were ruining the country".[\[294\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-N18_24_January_2020-294)[\[295\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_24_Jan_Maha_Bandh-295) - Curfew was imposed in Jharkhand's [Lohardaga district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lohardaga_district) after a clash and violence between pro and anti CAA protesters.[\[296\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-24_Jan_Lohardaga-296) - **25 January** - In London, around 2000 people from the Indian diaspora and the Human Rights organisation conducted a protest march against CAA from the Downing Street to the [Indian High Commission](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_House,_London).[\[297\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_2K_London-297)[\[298\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan-298) - More than a thousand women staged a sit-in protest at Frazer Town in Bangalore for 48 hours.[\[299\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-25_January_2020-299) - **26 January** - More than 300 eminent personalities in India including actor [Naseeruddin Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naseeruddin_Shah), [Javed Jaffrey](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javed_Jaffrey), and film-maker [Mira Nair](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mira_Nair) signed and issued an open statement against the CAA.[\[300\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_300_sign-300) - On the occasion of [Republic Day](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_Day_(India)), protests were held in Delhi,[\[301\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-301) Mumbai, Hyderabad, Chicago,[\[302\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-302) and London.[\[303\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-303) - 6-7 million people participated in a [human chain](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_chain_(politics)) extending from [Kasaragod](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasaragod) to [Kaliyikkavila](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaliyakkavilai) organised by the [LDF](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left_Democratic_Front_(Kerala)) in Kerala.[\[304\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:1-304) - **30 January** - A [juvenile](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juvenile_delinquency) [Hindu fundamentalist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_nationalism) opened fire at a protest at the [Jamia Milia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia), injuring one student.[\[305\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-305)[\[306\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:0-306)[\[307\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-307) The event happened on the 72nd anniversary of the [assassination of Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Mahatma_Gandhi), also by a Hindu fundamentalist. He was arrested and charged with attempted murder.[\[308\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-308) The man shouted slogans of " _[Jai Shri Ram](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jai_Shri_Ram)_" (Victory to Lord Rama) and " _Delhi Police Zindabad_" (Long live Delhi police).[\[309\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-309) - Bihar Police detained CPI leader [Kanhaiya Kumar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanhaiya_Kumar) before he could start his planned month-long "Jan-Gana-Man Yatra" which was organised at [Champaran](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Champaran) on [Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi)'s death anniversary.[\[310\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-310) - Seven protesters who were protesting at the Ghantaghar (Clock Tower) in Lucknow. They were arrested for taking out a candle march, which UP Police said was a violation of section 144 of the CrPC which was imposed in the area.[\[311\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-311) - **31 January** - Leaders from 14 opposition parties, led by the Indian National Congress, wore black armbands and vacated the front row seats to protest against the new law, the NRC and the NPR during President [Ram Nath Kovind](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ram_Nath_Kovind)'s address to the [Joint Session of the Parliament of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_Session_of_the_Parliament_of_India) for [2020 budget](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Union_budget_of_India) session. The Leader of the Opposition in the [Rajya Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajya_Sabha), [Ghulam Nabi Azad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghulam_Nabi_Azad) said that the Union Government misused the President's office and it was "shameful" that the government had included the CAA in the President's speech as an achievement.[\[312\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-312) ### February 2020 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=7) - **1 February** - After the JMI firing incident on 30 January, another Hindu fundamentalist fired bullets in the air during the [Shaheen Bagh protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests).[\[313\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:3-313) The man chanted the slogans " _Hindu Rashtra Zindabad_" (Long live the [Hindu Rashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_nationalism))[\[313\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:3-313) and " _Sirf Hinduo ki chalegi_" (Only Hindus will rule in this country).[\[314\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-314) - [Amnesty International](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International) informed US lawmakers that the CAA clearly violates the Constitution of India and [International human rights law](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_human_rights_law) and "legitimises discrimination" on the basis of religion.[\[315\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-315) - Thousands of LGBT rights activists protest raised slogans against the CAA at the [Queer Azaadi Pride Parade](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queer_Azaadi_Mumbai) in Mumbai.[\[316\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-316)[\[317\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-317) - **6 February** - In [Bidar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidar), a mother and a school principal were arrested after the mother's daughter participated in a play against the CAA.[\[318\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-318) - **7 February** - The Bidar police interrogated 85 school-children studying in classes 4–6 for participating in an anti-CAA play.[\[319\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-319) - Ahead of the [2020 Delhi Legislative Assembly election](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Delhi_Legislative_Assembly_election), two bike-borne men allegedly opened fired in the air near an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protest site in Northeast Delhi's Jafrabad. The police, however, suspected personal enmity.[\[320\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-320) - **8 February** - A Muslim BJP councillor in [Indore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indore) resigned from the party, accusing it of spreading "politics of hatred".[\[321\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-321) - **11 February** - [Jamia Milia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) students staged a march to the [Parliament](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_India) against the CAA and NRC. The march was stopped by the Delhi police who detained protesters.[\[322\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-322) The police allegedly sexually assaulted the protesters.[\[323\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-323) - **16 February** - [Imran Pratapgarhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohammad_Imran_Pratapgarhi), an Indian National Congress politician was fined ₹1.04 [crore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crore) (equivalent to ₹1.2 crore or US$147,000 in 2023) for violating Section 144 by addressing protestors, participating in an anti-CAA protest in [Moradabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moradabad), Uttar Pradesh, and allegedly instigating protesters at the Idgah ground.[\[324\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-324) - **17 February** - Over 150 prominent citizens including former judges, bureaucrats, army officers and academicians wrote to President Ram Nath Kovind, claiming that the anti-CAA protests were based on a false narrative, and urged the centre to look into the ongoing protests with all seriousness, safeguard the nation's democratic institutions and take stern action against the people behind them.[\[325\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-325)[\[326\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-326)[\[327\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-327) - [Magsaysay Award](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramon_Magsaysay_Award) recipient [Sandeep Pandey](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandeep_Pandey) was arrested by the Lucknow police for attempting to protest. He was released on bail after being produced in the District Magistrate's court.[\[328\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-328) - **18 February** - The Uttar Pradesh government informed the [Allahabad High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allahabad_High_Court) that 22 had been killed in the protests and a total of 883 people had been arrested in connection with violence during the protests.[\[329\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-329) - **19 February** - [Secretary-General of the United Nations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretary-General_of_the_United_Nations) [António Guterres](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres) expressed concerns over the possibility of millions being rendered [stateless](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stateless_nation) due to the CAA and NRC.[\[330\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-330)[\[331\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-331) - In [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai), a confederation of Muslim groups led a massive rally towards the [Secretariat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretariat_(administrative_office)) of Tamil Nadu in a demonstration against the CAA. It came a day after the [Madras High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madras_High_Court) denied permission to protesters to protest near[\[332\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-332) the state assembly and press for passage of a resolution against CAA, NRC and NPR. - **20 February** - [All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Majlis-e-Ittehadul_Muslimeen) leader and spokesperson [Waris Pathan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waris_Pathan) stoked controversy at a rally in Karnataka's [Gulbarga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulbarga) district by stating "To those saying we have only put our women at the forefront – only the lionesses are out and you're already sweating. Imagine what would happen if we all came together. We are 15 crore, but that can outweigh 100 crore, remember that."[\[333\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-333) The politician withdrew his statement on 23 February, saying that he had no intentions of hurting the sentiments of any community,[\[334\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-334) after criticism from both the ruling and opposition parties.[\[335\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-335) - **22 February** - About 200 Women gathered near the Jaffrabad Metro Station in Delhi at night protesting against the CAA and NRC.[\[336\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-336) - [Chief Minister of Maharashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_Maharashtra) [Uddhav Thackeray](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uddhav_Thackeray) decided to not pass a resolution against the CAA, making [Maharashtra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maharashtra) the first [UPA](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance)-ruled state to decide not to pass a resolution.[\[337\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-337) - **23 February** - The protest in the Jaffrabad Metro Station continued for the second day. Around 500 people mostly women gathered around the metro station that leads to closing the entry and exit from the metro station.[\[338\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-338)[\[339\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-339) - **24 February** The burnt shops at Shiv Vihar in [North East Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots). - One policeman and four protestors were killed and several shops and vehicles were burnt during a violent protest in Delhi.[\[340\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:4-340) - 13 people were killed in the [North East Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots).[\[341\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_News-341) - **25 February** - A shoot-at-sight order was issued in the evening by [Delhi Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Police) after the Anti-CAA and Pro-CAA protests became violent.[\[342\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-342) - The [Central Board of Secondary Education](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Board_of_Secondary_Education) postponed board examinations for classes 10 and 12 in northeast Delhi, in view of ongoing riots in the area. However, exams for the rest of Delhi and India would be conducted as per schedule.[\[343\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-343)[\[344\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-344) - **26 February** - The [Delhi High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_High_Court) in an emergency late-night hearing, asked the police to ensure safe passage for those injured in the [North East Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots) to the hospitals.[\[345\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-345) - The Delhi High Court asked the police to file [First information reports](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_information_report) against various politicians who were involved in making inflammatory speeches, provoking rioters in North East Delhi.[\[346\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-346) - **27 February** - One day after Delhi High Court judge [S. Muralidhar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/S._Muralidhar) directed Delhi police to file an FIR against those who had made inflammatory speeches, the [President of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India) ordered his transfer with the recommendation of [Supreme Court of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India).[\[347\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-347) ### March 2020 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=8) - **3 March** - The [UN High Commissioner](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Office_of_the_United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Human_Rights) filed an intervention application in the Supreme Court to be made a party in the case.[\[348\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UN_moves_to_SC-348) ### 2024 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=9) - **3 March** In response to the perceived lack of action by existing student unions, a new initiative called the Wesean Student Federation (WSF) was formed in March 2024.[\[349\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-349)[\[350\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-350) The WSF and other organisations like the Naga Student Federation has also sought international intervention on the issue, urging the [United Nations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Permanent_Forum_on_Indigenous_Issues) to address the discriminatory nature of the CAA and its potential threat to the sovereignty and rights of indigenous peoples in the region. [\[351\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-351)[\[352\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-352) ## Resolutions [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=10) So far, at least eight states have announced that they will not implement the Act or the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC). While one state and two [Union Territories](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Territories)[\[353\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-353) have refused to implement the CAA, three other states[\[354\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-354)[\[355\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-355) have only declined the implementation of the NRC. However, the [Union Home Ministry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) said that states lack the legal power to stop the implementation of Citizenship Amendment Act. ### Resolutions against CAA [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=11) - A resolution to scrap the CAA was moved by Chief Minister of Kerala, [Pinarayi Vijayan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinarayi_Vijayan) in the [Kerala Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_Legislative_Assembly). It was eventually passed by an absolute majority, with only the lone BJP MLA voting against it.[\[356\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-356) - The [Pattali Makkal Katchi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pattali_Makkal_Katchi), a member of the BJP-led [National Democratic Alliance](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance) passed a resolution against the NRC. It had urged the Central Government and the State [Government of Tamil Nadu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_Tamil_Nadu) not to extend the NRC in the state citing that it would create tension and fear in the society.[\[357\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-357) - The [Punjab Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab_Legislative_Assembly), that has the Indian National Congress in the majority, passed a resolution against the Act and urged the Modi Government to avoid discrimination on the basis of religion through the new Act. The resolution was moved by Punjab minister for parliamentary affairs [Brahm Mohindra](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brahm_Mohindra) of the [Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) and was supported by the [Aam Aadmi Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aam_Aadmi_Party) and the [Lok Insaaf Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Insaaf_Party).[\[358\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-358) - The [Rajasthan Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajasthan_Legislative_Assembly) that has the Indian National Congress in the majority, passed a resolution asking the Central government to repeal the CAA, making Rajasthan the third state to do so after Kerala and Punjab.[\[359\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rajasthan_Assembly-359) - A resolution to repeal the CAA was moved in the [West Bengal Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Bengal_Legislative_Assembly) by the [All India Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) headed by the Chief Minister, [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and eventually got passed on 27 January 2020, becoming the fourth state assembly to do so.[\[360\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-360) The West Bengal Assembly had also previously passed a resolution against the NRC in September 2019 and the first state assembly to pass a resolution against the proposed NRC.[\[361\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-361) - A five-page resolution against the CAA was drafted by 154 members of the [European Parliament](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Parliament),[\[362\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-362) who stated that it "marks a dangerous shift in the way citizenship will be determined in India and is set to create the largest statelessness crisis in the world and cause immense human suffering".[\[363\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Statelessness_Crisis-363) - The [Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh_Legislative_Assembly) passed a resolution against the CAA, becoming the fifth state to do so, after Rajasthan, West Bengal, Kerala and Punjab.[\[364\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-364) - The [Bihar Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar_Legislative_Assembly) on 25 February 2020 unanimously passed a resolution not to implement the NRC in the State. It also said the NPR would be implemented in Bihar in the old 2010 format.[\[365\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-365)[\[366\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-366) - The [National Assembly of Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan) passed a resolution labelling the Act as a "discriminatory law" and argued that it contravened "bilateral agreements and understandings between India and Pakistan, particularly those on security and rights of minorities in the respective countries".[\[367\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-367) - On 12 February 2020, [Puducherry Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puducherry_Legislative_Assembly) passed a resolution against the amended Citizenship Act, becoming the first union territory in the country to say no to the new law. The resolution passed by the Congress-led government in Puducherry also opposed the NRC and the NPR.[\[368\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-368)[\[369\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-369) - The [Gram panchayat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gram_panchayat) of Islak, of [Ahmednagar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmednagar_district), Maharastra passed a resolution in January 2020 against the CAA, the NRC and the NPR, becoming the first Indian Gram Panchayat to do so. After Islak, Ghatnandur of [Ambajogai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ambajogai), Maharastra, Loutolim of Goa and the panchayat of Patrud village of [Beed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beed_district), Maharastra have passed a resolutions against the CAA.[\[370\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-370)[\[371\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-371)[\[372\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-372)[\[373\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-373) - On 13 March 2020, The [Delhi Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Legislative_Assembly) passed a resolution against the CAA, becoming the second union territory to do so, after Puducherry.[\[374\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-374)[\[375\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-375) - The [Telangana Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telangana_Assembly) has passed a resolution opposing the CAA, the NPR and the NRC moved by the [Telangana Rashtra Samithi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telangana_Rashtra_Samithi) headed by the Chief minister [K. Chandrashekar Rao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._Chandrashekar_Rao). It has emerged as the 7th state to take decisions against the CAA, NPR and NCR. The resolution stated the Act as unconstitutional and urged the Union Government to remove all references to religion and any particular country.[\[376\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-376)[\[377\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-377) - Several US cities and counties — Seattle, Albany, St. Paul, Hamtramck, Cambridge, San Francisco, Riverdale and Alameda County — have passed resolutions against the CAA and NRC.[\[378\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Seattle_City_Council_Resolution-378)[\[379\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-379)[\[380\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-380)[\[381\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-381)[\[382\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-382) - On 13 July 2020, [New Westminster](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Westminster) in the province of British Columbia, Canada passed a resolution against CAA and urged the Canadian government to "take a position in opposition."[\[383\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-383)[\[384\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-384) - The [Sree Sankaracharya University of Sanskrit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sree_Sankaracharya_University_of_Sanskrit) (SSUS) at [Kalady](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalady) in [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) become the first university in the country to pass a resolution against the Citizenship Amendment Act by its syndicate in January 2020.[\[385\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-385) This was followed by [Calicut University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calicut_University) in the same month.[\[386\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-386) ## Protests [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=12) After the bill was approved on 4 December 2019, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) Reactionary protests were held as well in several metropolitan cities across India, including Delhi,[\[387\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-387) [Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore),[\[388\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-388) [Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad), [Hyderabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad),[\[389\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-389) [Jaipur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaipur), [Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata) and [Mumbai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai).[\[390\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-DC-HYD-390)[\[391\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-391) Reactionary protests were also held at universities across the country including [Cotton University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cotton_University),[\[392\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-392) [Gauhati University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_University),[\[393\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-393) [IIT Bombay](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Bombay),[\[390\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-DC-HYD-390) [Madras University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madras_University),[\[394\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-394) [Presidency University, Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_University,_Kolkata),[\[395\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-395) [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia),[\[396\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-396)[\[397\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-397) [Osmania University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osmania_University),[\[398\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-398) [University of Hyderabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Hyderabad), [University of Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Delhi),[\[399\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-399) [Panjab University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panjab_University)[\[400\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-400) and [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University).[\[401\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-401) By 16 December, the protests had spread across India with demonstrations occurring in at least 17 cities including [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai), [Jaipur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaipur), [Bhopal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhopal), [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow) and [Puducherry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pondicherry).[\[402\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-402)[\[403\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-403)[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) Between 16 and 18 December, a statement of solidarity "condemning the recent police action and brutalization of students at Jamia Millia University and Aligarh Muslim University" had acquired 10,293 signatories from over 1,100 universities, colleges and academic institutions across the world. Scholars from major academic institutions in India, including [JNU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/JNU_Delhi), [Delhi University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_University), all the [Indian Institutes of Technology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institutes_of_Technology), the [Indian Statistical Institute](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Statistical_Institute), the [Tata Institute of Fundamental Research](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Fundamental_Research), among many others had signed the solidarity statement.[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) On 16 December, professors and students of [IIM-Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Ahmedabad) were detained by police citing demonstrating protest against the Act is illegal.[\[405\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-405) On 19 December police banned protests in several parts of India with the imposition of [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unlawful_assembly#India) which prohibits the gathering of more than 4 individuals in a public space as being unlawful, namely, parts of the capital [New Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi), Uttar Pradesh, and [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka), including Bangalore. As Section 144 was imposed, the students of [IIM-Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Bangalore) demonstrate their protest peacefully by laying shoes and placards in front of the institute gate, which they called the Shoe [Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha).[\[406\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-406) Following IIM-Ahmedabad and Bangalore, [IIM-Calcutta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Calcutta) raised their voice peacefully in solidarity against the Act and the brutal misconduct by police against the students who were protesting all over the country.[\[407\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-407) Several institutes in [Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kozhikode) including [IIM-Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Kozhikode), [NIT-Calicut](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology_Calicut), [Government Medical College, Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Medical_College,_Kozhikode) and [Farook College](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farook_College) expressed their protest from 19 to 20 December.[\[408\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-408) Police in [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai) denied permission for marches, rallies or any other demonstration.[\[409\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-409)[\[410\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-410) Internet services were also shutdown in some parts of Delhi. As a result of defying the ban, thousands of protesters were detained, primarily in Delhi, including several opposition leaders and activists such as [Ramachandra Guha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramachandra_Guha), [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury), [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav), [Umar Khalid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umar_Khalid), [Sandeep Dikshit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandeep_Dikshit), and [D Raja](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/D_Raja).[\[411\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-411)[\[412\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-412)[\[413\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-413) Despite the fear of being detained, tens of thousands of people protested in Hyderabad, Patna, Chandigarh, Mumbai and other cities. Civil society groups, political parties, students, activists and ordinary citizens used social medial platforms to ask people to turn up and protest peacefully.[\[172\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_19_Dec-172) The protests involving 20,000 protesters concluded peacefully at the [August Kranti Maidan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Kranti_Maidan) at Mumbai.[\[179\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Mumbai_Mirror_19-179) More than 300 eminent personalities in India signed and issued an open statement against the CAA. The signatories including actor [Naseeruddin Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naseeruddin_Shah), Ratna Patak Shah, Jaaved Jafferi, Nandita Das, Lillete Dubey film-maker [Mira Nair](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mira_Nair), writers Anita Desai, Kiran Desai, actors, sociologist Ashis Nandy, activists Sohail Hashmi and Shabnam Hashmi among others.[\[300\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_300_sign-300) ### Assam [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=13) Mass Gathering of Anti Citizenship Act protests at Chandmari, [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), AssamA [Rangoli](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangoli) created as a part of protests against anti Citizenship Act 2019 at Chandmari, [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), Assam Students of [Cotton University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cotton_University) began protesting against the CAA a few days before the controversial bill was produced on the floor of the [Lok Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha). On 29 November, the students staged a silent protest outside the university campus.[\[414\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-414)[\[415\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-415) After the bill was cleared on 4 December 2019, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) _[Reuters](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuters)_ reported that the protests in the state were violent, adding that at least two people were killed till 16 December. Buildings and railway stations were set on fire. The CAA made 2014 as the cut-off date to determine illegal foreigners but according to people opposing the act, Assam bore the brunt of immigrants from 1951 to 1971, while other states did not.[\[416\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-416)[\[417\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-417)[\[418\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-418) The protesters were angry that the new law would allow thousands of [Bengali](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengali_language) speaking non-Muslim [immigrants from Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_India#Bangladeshi_immigrants) to become legal citizens of India,[\[155\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters16Dec-155)[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) thereby influencing the political and cultural environment of Assam.[\[419\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-419) Thousands of members and workers of the [All Assam Students Union (AASU)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) and 30 other indigenous organisations, artists, cultural activists of the state gathered at Latasil ground in Dispur to stage a [satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha) against the Act on 16, 17 and 18 December.[\[420\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-420)[\[162\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAASU-162) [Assam Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Police) subsequently detained the general secretary and the [adviser](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adviser) to the AASU and over 2,000 protesters in Guwahati during a protest rally on 18 December.[\[421\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-421)[\[422\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-422) On 12 December, security personnel, including [CRPF](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Reserve_Police_Force) jawans with batons and shields barged into the office of a private TV channel of Assam, _[Prag News](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prag_News)_ in Guwahati and attacked its staffers with batons during protests.[\[423\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-423) On 20 December, [Assamese language](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assamese_language) newspapers reported violent incidents occurring during the protests across the state. Use of excessive force by the police was also reported.[\[424\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-424) In [Dibrugarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dibrugarh), the All Assam Students Union members vandalised the district office of the [Asom Gana Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asom_Gana_Parishad), which had voted in favour of the act as part of the ruling Coalition.[\[425\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HBL-425)[\[426\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-426) Peasant leader [Akhil Gogoi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Gogoi) was arrested in [Jorhat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorhat) on 12 December as a preventive measure by authorities to prevent him from organising any protests. A special court of [National Investigation Agency](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Investigation_Agency) (NIA) in Guwahati on Tuesday charged him under [sedition](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedition) for " [maoist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maoism) links" and sent him to 10-day NIA custody. The [Assam Human rights Commission](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Human_rights_Commission) decided to take suo moto cognizance of reports of alleged torture upon Akhil Gogoi.[\[427\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-427)[\[428\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-428) According to the [Assam Government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Government), people have been arrested by the Assam Police for their alleged involvement in the violent incidents during the anti-CAA protests across the state, as of 17 December.[\[146\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAkhil19-146)[\[429\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-429) In [Dispur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispur), several thousands of protesters broke down police barricades to protest in front of the [Assam Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Legislative_Assembly) building.[\[430\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-430)[\[134\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-New_York_Times-134) Demonstrations were also held in [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[431\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-431) On 15 December 2019, a concert was staged by artistes of Assam as a protest against the CAA. The concert was themed as 'No CAA, Concert for peace and harmony'. Along with music, paintings were also demonstrated in the event.[\[432\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-432)[\[433\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-433) Access to the internet was restricted in Assam by the administrative authorities.[\[103\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_arrests-103) A curfew was also declared in Assam and [Tripura](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripura) due to the protests,[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) leading to army deployment as protesters defied the curfews. Railway services were suspended and some airlines started to waive rescheduling or cancellation fees in those areas.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Officials reported that at least four people died after clashes with police in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati).[\[434\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-434)[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Two men, Dipanjal Das and Sam Stafford, died due to police firing on 12 December.[\[145\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto3-145)[\[435\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-435) On 15 December, [Gauhati Medical College and Hospital](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_Medical_College_and_Hospital) official stated that Ishwar Nayak died on the night of 14 December and Abdul Alim died on 15 December morning. Both of them had been admitted to the hospital after suffering gunshot wounds.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) As of 15 December, it was reported that at least 6 people had died due to police firing during the protests.[\[436\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-436) After ten days of restriction, mobile internet services in the state were restored from 20 December, although the [Gauhati High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_High_Court) had ordered the government of Assam to restore the service by 5 pm on 19 December.[\[437\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-437) By 22 December, the number of arrested people rose to 393, with 28 cases being registered for making offensive and provocative posts on social media.[\[438\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto4-438) On 21 December, an all-woman protest was organised across the state.[\[184\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ReutersHundreds-184) Senior citizens across the state protested on 23 December.[\[439\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-439) Chowkidinghee playground in [Dibrugarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dibrugarh_district) saw one of the largest mass gatherings of CAA protests in Assam organised by All Assam Students' Union on 24 December.[\[440\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-440) On 8 January, PM Modi cancelled his visit to Assam while the protests continued in the state. AASU had planned huge protests during Modi's visit.[\[240\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Modi_8_Jan-240)[\[241\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_8_Jan-241) Thousands of people joined the anti-CAA protests at Dibrugarh, Guwahati and other parts of Assam.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242) The protesters dressed up in traditional dress of the region and sang devotional songs during the protest. The protesters also demanded the release of Akhil Gogoi and called the [Modi government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modi_government) a dictatorship.[\[243\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-nenow_8_January_2020-243) On 9 January, musical protests were planned at Gauhati Club in Assam by AASU, along with 30 other organisations and artist communities.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242) On 22 January, thousands of students from 9 universities in North East India boycotted classes and joined a protest march in the states of Assam, [Nagaland](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagaland), Meghalaya and [Arunachal Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh).[\[284\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_22_Jan_Assam-284) ### Tripura [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=14) Several protests marches with thousands of protesters were held in Tripura. On 12 December _BBC_ reported that the army had been deployed in the state and around 1800 people were arrested.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Around 200 protesters were detained by police during a protest in the capital city of [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[441\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-441) On 11 December, [Pradyot Manikya Debbarma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pradyot_Manikya_Debbarma), the royal scion, led the largest protest in Tripura so far consisting of thousands of people.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) Debbarma stated that beneficiaries of CAA would not be allowed to settle in Tripura. He added that the state has already accommodated many migrants from [East Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Pakistan) and further immigration due to CAA would endanger the threatened indigenous residents of the state.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) The Act also ignited old conflicts between the Bengalis and the [Reang refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reang#The_Displaced_Reangs). Fresh clashes were reported in the northern district of [Kanchanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanchanpur_District) between the two communities. The Reang refugees were protesting against the CAA while the Hindu Bengalis were supporting it. Protesters reportedly threw stones and vandalised shops and a marketplace.[\[442\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-442) ### Crackdown on Universities [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=15) #### Jamia Millia Islamia [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=16) Main article: [2019 Jamia Milia Islamia attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jamia_Milia_Islamia_attack) On 13 December 2019, the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia_University) undertook a march to the Parliament protesting against the CAA. They were prevented from going ahead by the police who used batons and tear gas to disperse the protesters leading to clashes with them. Fifty students were detained by the police after the clash. According to the students, police attacked the peaceful protesters with stones and sticks, and several students were injured. The students then retaliated, and clashes ensued. Police denied the allegations, also claiming that the protesters attacked the policemen with stones after they were stopped from marching onwards. Police then used tear gas to disperse them.[\[443\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Hindu_13_Jamia-443) On the morning of 15 December 2019, more than two thousand students of Jamia joined the protests against CAA in Delhi.[\[444\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CNN_spread-444) Jamia Millia Student Body and Jamia Millia Islamia Teacher's Association (JTA) condemned the violence that happened on the same day in Delhi and stated that no student or teacher was involved in the violence.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) At 6:46 pm on 15 December 2019, hundreds of police officers forcefully entered the campus of Jamia, without the permission of college authority.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) The police used batons and tear gas on the protesting students.[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) Nearly a hundred students were detained by the Delhi police and released at 3:30 am next morning.[\[445\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Police_station-445) The visuals of students being dragged and [assaulted](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assaulted) by the police was telecast by news channels. Students from all across Delhi joined the agitation.[\[446\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-446) About two hundred people were injured[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) and were admitted to [AIIMS](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Institute_of_Medical_Sciences,_New_Delhi) and the [Holy Family Hospital](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Holy_Family_Hospital_(New_Delhi)&action=edit&redlink=1).[\[447\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Jamia_16-447) Anti-CAA Banner demonstrated at Cultural Protest organised by Artistes of Assam at AEI ground, Chandmari, [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati). On 16 December 2019, two students of Jamia were admitted to the [Safdarjung Hospital](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safdarjung_Hospital) with bullet injuries received during the protests on 15 December.[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) One of the victims, M. Tamin stated that he was not participating in the protest and was passing through the area on a motorcycle, when police suddenly started caning the protesters and he was shot in the leg by police from point blank range.[\[448\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-India_Today_Tamin-448) According to the doctors treating him, the wounds were from a gunshot.[\[449\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-449)[\[450\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-450)\[ _[non-primary source needed](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources)_\] The police stated that they were investigating the allegations of gunshot.[\[447\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Jamia_16-447) The vice-chancellor stated that they will file a court case against the police, demanding an investigation on how police entered the university premises and assaulted the students.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79)[\[155\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters16Dec-155) On 15 December, Delhi Police attacked students of Jamia Millia Islamia including Shaheen Abdullah, Chanda Yadav, Ladeeda Farzana and [Aysha Renna](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aysha_Renna) at New Friends Colony.[\[451\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-451) The university was shut until 5 January 2020 and the residents were asked to leave the campus.[\[452\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HinduLiveCAA-452) Response The police violence was heavily criticised by filmmaker [Anurag Kashyap](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anurag_Kashyap), actor [John Cusack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Cusack) and [Rajkummar Rao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajkummar_Rao) condemned the police violence, with Cusack referring it to [fascism](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascism) and Kashyap calling the government to be "clearly fascist".[\[453\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kashyap-453)[\[454\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-454) Actor [Swara Bhaskar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swara_Bhaskar), praised the students protests for raising their voice against communalism and called the police action as dictatorial, brutal, shocking and shameful. She also questioned if it was the police and not the protesters who vandalised the property in Delhi and Aligarh.[\[455\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Swara-455) [Amnesty International India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amnesty_International_India) criticised the police for the violence against the students of Jamia and Aligarh University and stated that the allegations of police brutality and sexual harassment against the students should be investigated and culprits be punished.
