Defending the right of the students to protest, its director stated that the arrest of protesters violate India's obligations under the Article 19 and Article 21 of the [International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Covenant_on_Civil_and_Political_Rights) (ICCPR), to respect and protect the right to freedom of expression and peaceful assembly.[\[452\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HinduLiveCAA-452) _No to police brutality graffiti_ on a metro wall in New Delhi In response to the police crackdown in Jamia Millia Islamia University and Aligarh Muslim University, protests were also joined by the students of the educational institutions of [IIT Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IIT,_Kanpur), [IIT Madras](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/IIT_Madras), [Jadavpur University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jadavpur_University), [Tata Institute of Social Sciences](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Social_Sciences,_Hyderabad), [IISc](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Science_(IISc),_Bangalore), [Pondicherry University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pondicherry_University), [IIM Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Ahmedabad),[\[456\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-456) as well as organisations such as [Pinjra Tod](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinjra_Tod) and the [Students' Federation of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Students%27_Federation_of_India).[\[457\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BSDelhiCondemn-457) The students of Jadavpur University, West Bengal, called a protest gathering on 16 December, to "condemn the brutal [state terror](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_terrorism) on the students of Jamia Millia Islamia University".[\[458\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-thenewsminute-458) At the event of IIT Kanpur, communal slogans were also raised by the protesters.[\[459\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-459) A placard on the 23rd day of [protests at Shaheen Bagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests); in solidarity with AMU JMI JNU, 8 January 2020 in New Delhi .Aftermath On 17 December, police arrested ten people (some of them having criminal history) in the case of the violent clashes in Jamia. None of the arrested were students of Jamia.[\[460\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_10_arrested-460) On 13 January, several student groups protested outside the office of Vice-Chancellor asking to reschedule the exam dates, filing a case against Delhi Police and ensuring the safety of students. The VC announced in the afternoon, that a case will be filed against police on 14 January.[\[254\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_live_13_Jan-254) On 15 January, the VC met Delhi police commissioner to discuss the violence and urged him to file an FIR.[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) The Registrar of JMI filed a petition in a Delhi court for filing FIR on the violence at JMI. The court directed Delhi Police to submit by 16 March, a report on the actions taken on JMI administration's complaint.[\[461\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-23_Jan_JMI_report-461) #### Aligarh Muslim University [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=17) On 15 December, protests against CAA were held outside the campus of the [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University).[\[462\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-462) On the evening of 15 December, police officers forcefully entered the campus of the university and assaulted the students. At least 60 students were injured including the president of the students Union. The access to the internet was restricted in the area by the district administration. The university was closed from 15 December till 5 January 2020.[\[157\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Aligarh-157) A report by three activist-lawyers alleged that the police had resorted to "deceptive shelling", firing explosives camouflaged as tear gas shells during the crackdown.[\[463\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-463) On the evening of 17 December, police released 26 people (including 8 students) on personal bonds. They had been arrested on charges of violence.[\[464\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_CAA_17_Dec-464) On 19 December, [People's Union for Democratic Rights](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Union_for_Democratic_Rights)' fact-finding team consisting of activists [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav), [Harsh Mander](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harsh_Mander) and [Kavita Krishnan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kavita_Krishnan) released a report on police crackdown at the Aligarh Muslim University. The report alleged that the police had called the students as terrorists and had used religiously charged slogans such as " _[Jai Shri Ram](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jai_Shri_Ram)_". The report also accused the police of breaking the protocols of the campus. It added that no bullet injury was reported. The report was prepared after visiting the campus, based on the video and audio clips of the incident, statements of the injured students and witnesses.[\[465\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-465) After a lull of four days, on 20 December, AMU campus again witnessed protests on Saturday with hundreds of AMU non-teaching staff joining hands with AMU teachers' association, protesting against the CAA and "police atrocities" against the agitators in various parts of the state.[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) On 24 December 1000 – 1200 protesters were booked after organising a candle march inside [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University) for violating section 144.[\[203\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto7-203) On 15 January, Aligarh Muslim University postponed all exams due to the ongoing CAA protests.[\[266\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AMU_postpones_exams_15_Jan-266) Aftermath At 7 am on 16 January, Vice-Chancellor met the protesting students and expressed regret for calling police inside the AMU campus to handle the law and order situation inside campus. He defended his decision stating he had not thought that the police would enter the hostels. AMU had set up a fact-finding committee headed by Justice (retd.) V.K. Gupta for a detailed investigation of the events that occurred in the night of 15 December. The VC asked to students to cooperate with the fact-finding committee and the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) team that was visiting the campus.[\[467\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AMU_V-C_16_Jan-467) #### Nadwa College [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=18) On 16 December, around 300 students of [Nadwa college](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadwa_University), in Lucknow had planned a peaceful protest march against CAA and in solidarity with the students of AMU. The police prevented students from holding the march and forced them to return into the campus premises. The police locked the gates of the campus from outside and guarded it with a heavy deployment of police to prevent the students from coming out of the campus and undertaking the planned march.[\[160\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_Nadwa-160) A clash between the police and the students locked inside the campus ensued and involved [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting) from both sides.[\[468\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Nadwa_video-468)[\[469\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Stone_Pelting_Cops-469) The police officers were seen hitting the students with sticks as in the video footage of the incident telecast on news channels.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79)[\[470\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Nadwa-470) Around 15 to 20 students were injured. 30 students were charged by the police for attempt to murder, rioting etc. The police accused the students of blocking the road and engaging in violence by throwing stones.[\[161\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Exp_Nadwa_17_Dec-161) While the students claimed that the police had attacked the unarmed students who were holding a peaceful protest. The student stated that they were neither involved in any violence, nor did they block any roads and yet they were charged with batons. After the incident the college was shut down until 5 January, and the students were asked to leave the campus.[\[161\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Exp_Nadwa_17_Dec-161) #### Jawaharlal Nehru University [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=19) Main article: [2020 JNU Attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_JNU_Attack) On 5 January, at 6:30pm, a masked mob consisting of more than 60–100 people armed with rods and sticks attacked the campus of [Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University,_Delhi).[\[236\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Masked_JNU-236)[\[471\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-471) The assault and vandalism lasted for 3 hours, where the mob chanted slogans exclaiming the victims to be "naxalites" and "anti-national".[\[472\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-472) The mob assaulted journalists and social activist, [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav) in the presence of media and police, who attempted to enter the campus on receiving news of the incident.[\[473\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-473) The mob also punctured the tires of ambulances attending to the victims of the assault which had left more than 42 students and teachers as severely injured. Street lights were shut off by authorities during the incident. Students of the campus including the [JNUSU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_University_Students%27_Union) president, Aishe Ghosh who was brutally attacked on head and was hospitalised, alleged the police of intentional inaction as police were informed before the assault about unknown groups entering in the campus.[\[474\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-474)[\[475\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-475) Around 30 students who were members of the left wing groups were injured along with 12 teachers. Visually impaired students were also not spared from assault.[\[476\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-476) The students and left wing organisations accused the members of the BJP's student wing, [Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Bharatiya_Vidyarthi_Parishad) of orchestrating the attacks, while ABVP accused the left wing organisations.[\[236\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Masked_JNU-236) Professors who tried to intervene and save the students were also attacked. The policemen inside the campus allegedly did nothing to stop the mob.[\[236\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Masked_JNU-236)[\[477\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_JNU_4_Jan-477) The assault was orchestrated through a WhatsApp group called "Unity against Left" which were traced through messages from members of the ABVP in the group.[\[478\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-478)[\[479\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-479) Students in Mumbai, launched a protest called "Occupy Gateway" late at night to protest against the assault.[\[480\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-480) As a reaction to the assault, protests occurred across the country and in several cities.[\[481\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-481) ### Delhi [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=20) Locals in New Delhi protest against CAAA major road in New Delhi has been blocked by anti CAA protests for over three weeks in the [Shaheen Bagh protests](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protests). (pic taken on 7 January 2020).[\[482\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-482) On 14 December 2019, thousands of agitators packed into [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar,_New_Delhi) Road, filling up a space estimated to be half the size of a football ground, as multiple demonstrations occurred against the CAA in Delhi.[\[150\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_Jantar-150)[\[151\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Jantar-151) The next day in Delhi near New Friends Colony, three [Delhi Transport Corporation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Transport_Corporation) buses were torched.[\[153\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:5-153)[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) On 16 December, [Priyanka Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priyanka_Gandhi) led a silent protest at the [India Gate](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_Gate) along with about three hundred congress workers to show solidarity with the students of Jamia Millia Islamia.[\[49\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Priyanka_Gandhi-49) On 17 December 2019, Delhi's Seelampur area had stone-throwing crowds face off against the police. The police retaliated with tear gas and batons, in which, according to local reports, several protesters and officers were injured. There were also reports of a police station being set on fire. According to police, buses were vandalised in the area.[\[164\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc_Seelampur-164) On 19 December 2019, the administrative authorities imposed a ban against public gatherings in parts of Delhi.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) 20 metro stations were closed to prevent the movement for protests.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168) At least 700 flights were delayed and more than 20 cancelled due to traffic jams caused by police closing the roads to stifle protests.[\[174\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Flights-174) Protest meetings were held defying the ban in Red Fort and [Mandi House](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandi_House).[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) Access to the mobile internet was restricted in certain places in Delhi.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169) Digital rights activists, who accessed and studied the order suspending internet in several areas in Delhi on 19 December, stated that it was not issued from the "right channels" and, therefore, was "illegal".[\[483\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto-483) Politicians [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav), [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury), [Nilotpal Basu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nilotpal_Basu), [Brinda Karat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brinda_Karat), [Ajay Maken](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajay_Maken), [Brinda Karat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brinda_Karat), [Prakash Karat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prakash_Karat), [Sandeep Dikshit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandeep_Dikshit), [Umar Khalid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umar_Khalid) and [D. Raja](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/D._Raja) along with around 1,200 protesters were detained by the police.[\[169\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Shah_Meeting-169)[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168)[\[484\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-484) On 20 December 2019, two Delhi Metro stations – [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia_metro_station) and [Jasola Vihar Shaheen Bagh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jasola_Vihar_Shaheen_Bagh_metro_station) were closed. Amid nationwide crackdown because of CAA, [Bhim Army](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhim_Army) Chief [Chandrashekhar Azad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandrashekhar_Azad_(social_activist))'s permission for the march from Jama Masjid to [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar) had been denied by [Delhi Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Police). In spite of the denial of permission and the imposition of [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144), a protest march was held where Azad was able to escape after being detained by the police.[\[181\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Bhim-181)[\[485\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-485) The protests were peaceful throughout the day, but in the evening a car was torched in Daryaganj after which the police attacked the protesters with water cannons and lathi charge.[\[486\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_6_killed-486) On the aftermath, Chandrashekhar Azad accused the [Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh) of being responsible for the violence and sought for the resignation of the [Union Home Minister](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Home_Minister), Amit Shah.[\[487\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-487) On 21 December, Chandrashekhar Azad was arrested along with 27 people and three FIRs were registered for the violent incidents on 20 December at Delhi Gate and Seemapuri.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 10 January 12 of those arrested were released on bail.[\[488\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_released_10_Jan-488) On 15 January, a Delhi court granted bail and released Chandrashekhar Azad aka "Raavan".[\[265\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Azad_bail_15_Jan-265) However, when presented in the Delhi Tis Hazari court on 14 January 2020, the court questioned the public prosecutor about what is wrong with protesting since many people who protested in past are sitting chairpersons in the present government.[\[489\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-489) Protests were conducted by the journalists against the police brutality on the journalists covering the Anti-CAA protests especially in the states of Delhi, Uttar Pradesh and Karnataka. In the protests, [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury) stated that only the states ruled by the [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) were experiencing violence. He further added that the other states were peaceful and hinted that the differences between the situation in the states show the who were encouraging violence.[\[490\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-490) On 23 December 2019, protests were held at multiple locations. 93 other students protesting outside Assam Bhawan and demanding the release of RTI activist Akhil Gogoi were detained by the police. The students alleged that the police used violence on the protesters.[\[491\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto5-491)[\[492\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-492) On 24 December 2019, Police imposed a ban on gatherings in central Delhi's [Mandi House](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandi_House) near the Lutyens' Zone to prevent the protest march of students from multiple universities. The anti CAA-NRC protest march was to start from Mandi House to [Jantar Mantar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jantar_Mantar).[\[493\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-493)[\[494\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-494) On 27 December, the Delhi Police used [facial recognition software](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_recognition_software) by recording a video of the protester and checking it with the database of criminals maintained by them.[\[495\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Face_Recognition_28_Dec-495) On 14 January, [Supreme Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) lawyers conducted a protest march from the Supreme Court to Jantar Mantar to protest against the CAA, NRC and NPR.[\[496\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-496) On 19 January, in Delhi, hundreds of protesters joined a protest march holding lighted candles from Jamia University to Shaheen Bagh.[\[272\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Delhi_candle-272) Some of the protesters had dressed up as [Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi), [BR Ambedkar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BR_Ambedkar) and other revolutionaries of the [Indian Independence movement](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Independence_movement). A model of detention camp was also paraded in the march.[\[272\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_Delhi_candle-272) #### North East Delhi riots [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=21) Main article: [2020 Delhi riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Delhi_riots) Many Cars burnt by Mob in Shiv ViharThe burnt Gym at Shiv Vihar. On 24 February, [violent clashes](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_East_Delhi_riots) occurred at [Jaffrabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jaffrabad,_Delhi) and Maujpur in which one police officer and a protester were killed. The pro-CAA demonstrators indulged in stone pelting with the anti-CAA protesters and vandalised houses, vehicles and shops. The police personnel used [tear gas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tear_gas) and [lathicharge](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lathicharge) against the protestors.[\[497\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-497)[\[498\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-498) Later, it was reported that four protestors also died during the violence.[\[340\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:4-340) The [Ministry of Home Affairs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) stated that the violence appeared orchestrated because of U.S. President [Donald Trump](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump)'s visit to India.[\[499\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-499) On 26 February, The [United States Commission on International Religious Freedom](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Commission_on_International_Religious_Freedom) (USCIRF) condemned the violence in New Delhi.[\[500\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-500) USCIRF Chair [Tony Perkins](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tony_Perkins_(politician)) said, "We urge the Indian government to make serious efforts to protect Muslims and others targeted by mob violence."[\[501\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-501) The Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) has also condemned the New Delhi violence. It stated that steps must be taken to prevent the incidents of " [Islamophobia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamophobia)" in the country. The OIC statement further went on to add that it "condemns the recent and alarming violence against Muslims in India, resulting in the death and injury of innocent people and the arson and vandalism of mosques and Muslim-owned properties."[\[502\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-502) The Government of India (GOI) has reacted by describing the criticism from the OIC as "inaccurate, selective, and misleading." The GOI also described USCIRF's criticism as "factually inaccurate and misleading, and appear to be aimed at politicising the issue." [\[503\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-503) #### Shaheen Bagh [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=22) Main article: [Shaheen Bagh protest](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheen_Bagh_protest) Shaheen Bagh on New Year's Eve. Since 14 December, a continuous 24/7 sit in protest is being conducted. The protest began in the afternoon of 14 December with just 15 local women, and went on to gather thousands of protesters with crowds reaching as high as 100,000 on Sundays.[\[504\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-504)[\[505\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-505) On New Year's Eve, thousands of protesters camping at the site sung the [Indian national anthem](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_national_anthem).[\[506\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-506) They were joined in by celebrities and activists on 31 December.[\[507\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-507) But in a turn of events, the protest took a turn for the worst when anti India slogans were shouted at Shaheen Bagh with reference to Jinnah and a call out to try and break India ( _Jinnah wali Azadi_), where many miscreants with their own agenda had joined.[\[508\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-508) The day was also recorded to have been the coldest in Delhi in the past 100 years.[\[509\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-509) On 10 January, the [Delhi High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_High_Court) rejected a plea to shift the Shaheen Bagh protesters.[\[510\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-510) The area has been covered with protest artwork.[\[511\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-511) ### West Bengal [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=23) On Saturday, 14 December 2019, violent protests occurred in West Bengal as the protesters attacked railway stations and public buses. Five trains were set on fire by the protesters in [Lalgola](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lalgola_railway_station) and [Krishnapur railway stations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnapur_railway_station) in [Murshidabad district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad_district); railway tracks were also damaged in Suti.[\[159\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_14Dec-159) On Monday, 16 December 2019, tens of thousands of people joined a protest march led by Chief Minister [Mamata Banerjee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee) and her ruling [Trinamool Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Trinamool_Congress) party.[\[79\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_Plea-79) Mamata Banerjee stated that the NRC and CAA would not be implemented in West Bengal state as long as she was alive. She appealed people not to resort to violence, while accusing people from outside the state and members of the [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) of engaging in arson.[\[512\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-512)[\[513\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-513) On Tuesday, 17 December 2019, protests that included road and rail blockades continued in parts of West Bengal including the districts of [South 24 Parganas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_24_Parganas), [North 24 Parganas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_24_Parganas_district) and [Nadia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadia_district).[\[514\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-514) On 19 December 2019, a crowd with thousands of protesters gathered at Moulali in central Kolkata to peacefully object CAA and NRC.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) Mamata Banerjee held a second rally in Kolkata and stated that the Central Government was trying to project the CAA Protests as though it was a Hindu vs Muslim fight.[\[168\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_3_lives-168) She also stated that "BJP is buying skull caps for its cadres who are wearing them while vandalising properties to malign a particular community,".[\[515\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_Kolkata_Rally-515) Earlier, on 18 December, a young [BJP](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/BJP) worker along with five associates, wearing [lungi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lungi) and [skullcap](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taqiyah_(cap)) were seen by the local residents throwing stones on a train engine. The arsonists were caught by the locals who handed them to the [Murshidabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murshidabad) police.[\[516\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-516)[\[517\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-517)[\[518\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-518) On 21 December 2019, a protest march that the police estimated to be of 10,000 people was held in [Kolkata](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata) from [Shahid Minar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaheed_Minar,_Kolkata) till [Mahajati Sadan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahajati_Sadan).[\[185\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TelegraphFloodgates-185) Between 13 and 17 December 2019, multiple incidents of violence were reported during the protests. According to the police, as of 21 December, more than 600 people had been arrested for allegedly being involved in the violence.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 23 December 2019, Governor [Jagdeep Dhankhar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jagdeep_Dhankhar) was stopped by the students at [Jadavpur University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jadavpur_University), from attending the university convocation ceremony. The vice-president of the BJP West Bengal unit raised questions that why the Muslims were excluded from the amendment if it was not about religion.[\[519\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-519) On 24 December 2019, Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee lead a protest march in Kolkata from [Swami Vivekananda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda) statue at [Bidhan Sarani](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidhan_Sarani). She accused PM Narendra Modi and Union Home Minister Amit Shah of making contradictory statements. She stated "The prime minister is saying there has been no discussion or proposal on NRC. But a few days ago, BJP president and Union Home Minister Amit Shah had said NRC exercise would be carried out across the country. Both the statements are contradictory. We wonder who is speaking the truth. They are trying to create confusion,".[\[520\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-520) On 3 January, the radical Islamic organisation [Popular Front of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_Front_of_India) (PFI) had planned an anti CAA protest for 5 January, but the West Bengal police denied permission for it.[\[521\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_PFI_3_Jan-521) Since 7 January, women had been conducting a sit in protest at the grounds of Park Circus in Kolkata.[\[239\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Park_Circus_16_Jan-239) On 11 January, PM Modi visited Kolkata on a two-day official visit. Hundreds of people protested against CAA at the Kolkata airport.[\[247\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Rediff_11_Jan-247) Several parties and student unions launched a protest at the Dorina Crossing at Esplanade in Kolkata. SFI leader stated that the protests would continue till Sunday, until PM Modi (who had been visiting the city) was in Kolkata.[\[248\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_11_Jan-248) On 22 January, a 5 kilometre long procession against CAA was led by CM Mamta Bannerjee in [Darjeeling](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darjeeling), West Bengal. The participants wore ethnic dresses and also played musical instruments. The participants chanted anti CAA slogans and carried banners and posters.[\[287\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-22_Jan_Darjeeling-287) On 26 January (Republic Day), thousands formed parallel 11 km long human chains from [Shyambazar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shyambazar) to Golpark in Kolkata.[\[522\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-522) ### Punjab [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=24) Protests begun in [Malerkotta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malerkotla), [Patiala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patiala) and [Ludhiana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludhiana) with the support of [Khalsa Aid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khalsa_Aid), Alliance of Sikh Organisations and various Dalit organisations.[\[523\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-523) By 17 December, protests were being held in [Amritsar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amritsar), Malerkotla, [Machhiwara](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machhiwara), [Bathinda](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bathinda) and [Ludhiana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludhiana). Students of [Panjab University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panjab_University), [Punjabi University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjabi_University) and [Central University of Punjab](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_University_of_Punjab) took a leading role in the protests backed by the Association of Democratic Rights. [Razia Sultana](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Razia_Sultana_(politician)), the only Muslim MLA and a Minister of the [Punjab Cabinet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Amarinder_Singh_ministry) organised a large protest in Malerkotla.[\[524\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-524) A cabinet meeting in Punjab decided to proceed as per the decision of the state assembly. A statement was released stating, "The ministers also expressed concern over the implications of the blatantly unconstitutional and divisive CAA, NRC and NPR," They also expressed concern on the violence over CAA stating, the issue "threatened to rip apart the secular fabric of the nation".[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) ### Uttar Pradesh [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=25) Main article: [CAA protests in Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAA_protests_in_Uttar_Pradesh) Protests were held in [Aligarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh), [Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanpur), [Bareilly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bareilly), [Varanasi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Varanasi) and [Lucknow](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucknow).[\[525\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-525) [Banaras Hindu University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banaras_Hindu_University) students also protested the police action targeting AMU and Jamia students.[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526) However, they also held a rally in support of the CAA and NRC.[\[527\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-527) On 19 December, the administration banned public assembly all over the state to prevent further protests in the state. Access to the internet was restricted in [Azamgarh district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azamgarh_district) for 2 days, after protest continued for 2 days in the area.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) In Lucknow, several buses, cars, media vans and motorbikes were torched. [Uttar Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh) Chief Minister [Yogi Adityanath](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogi_Adityanath) stated that the authorities would seize the properties of those who indulge in violence in the state.[\[528\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-528) On 20 December 2019, six protesters are killed in police firing in UP.[\[180\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_6_deaths_in_up-180) According to the [Press Trust of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Press_Trust_of_India), the death toll from Friday's protests in Uttar Pradesh's 13 districts has risen to 11.[\[69\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-al_jazeera-69) On 21 December 2019, violent protests along with alleged police brutality were reported from several districts across the state. Access to the internet was restricted. The number of fatalities in the state increased to 16.[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) Multiple clashes causing injuries to several people were reported. According to the police, 263 policemen were injured, of which 57 were firearm injuries. NDTV later reported that they could only find one policeman with bullet wound and the police did not share the list of 57 policemen with bullet injuries.[\[529\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_4_Jan_bullet-529) Police arrested 705 people in the state, with 102 arrested for making allegedly objectionable remarks or social media posts.[\[530\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-530)[\[466\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Cops263-466) According to the UP Police, as of 21 December, a total of 218 people had been arrested in Lucknow.[\[182\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_16_Killed-182) On 24 December, [Uttar Pradesh Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh_Police) stated that 21,500 people were charged in 15 FIRs for violent incidents in Kanpur.[\[531\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-531) In [Muzaffarnagar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muzaffarnagar) the government, sealed 67 shops. Chief Minister, Adityanath had threatened the protesters that his government would auction the properties of the rioters to recover the losses due to the damage made to the property.[\[200\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18Muzaffarnagar-200)[\[201\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-SiasatRakshak-201)[\[532\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-532)[\[202\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTVVandalising-202) On 26 December, In Sambhal, UP, the government sent notices to 26 people for their alleged involvement in damaging properties during protests and asked them to explain their position or pay for the loss due to damage of property. The losses to the property were assessed to be [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)11.66 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$14,000).[\[204\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sambhal_Damage-204) Earlier, on 22 December, the UP government had created a panel to assess the damage to the property and to recover the losses by seizing the property of the alleged protesters.[\[191\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Lucknow_22_Dec_IT-191) The social activists accused the government of intimidating the protesters.[\[533\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-533) On 28 December, the _Indian Express_ reported that with 19 killed and 1,246 people arrested based on 372 FIRs lodged in the state, UP was the worst affected state with the biggest police crackdown in India.[\[206\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_Express_live_28_Dec-206) Even though the official figure of number of deaths so far in UP was 19, opposition parties claimed that the actual figure was higher. The UP police had maintained that the deaths of protesters were not the result of police firing, but later on they admitted that some deaths were indeed caused by the police but attributed those incidents to shots fired in self defence.[\[534\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Deaths_5_Jan-534) On 17 January in Lucknow, around 500 women along with their children started a sit in protest at 2 pm near the Clock Tower.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270)(subscription required)[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) The police tried to convince them to end the protest but the protesters refused to move. On the night of 18 January, Uttar Pradesh police cracked down on the CAA protesters and snatched their blankets, utensils and food items.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) The video of policemen carrying away the blankets was recorded and shared on social media. The conduct of UP police was criticised by the users and the phrase "KAMBALCHOR\_UPPOLICE" (blanket thief UP Police) became the top trend on Twitter in India.[\[271\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-UP_blanket_19_Jan-271) The police responded saying that they had confiscated the blankets following due procedure. The protesters alleged that police also cut the electricity connection to the ground, locked the public toilet nearby and poured water on the bonfire in the winter night.[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) The police had issued a prohibition on assembly in Lucknow,[\[535\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-19_Jan_CAA_blanket-535) and stated that they will prosecute the protesters for violating it.[\[270\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TH_19_Jan_blanket-270) On 21 January, police registered cases against 160 women for violation of the ban on assembly and protesting against CAA in Lucknow.[\[281\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-160_booked_21_Jan-281) On 16 December, in response to the police crackdown at Jamia Millia University in Delhi and Aligarh Muslim University over the Citizenship Amendment Act, clashes between the police and protesters occurred in Dakshintola area of [Mau](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mau,_Uttar_Pradesh), Uttar Pradesh. On 17 December, students of [IIT Kanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Technology_Kanpur) assembled in a peaceful protest against the CAA and to express solidarity with the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia).[\[536\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-536) ### Karnataka [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=26) On 16 December, protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) were held in various parts of [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka). In [Mysore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mysore), hundreds of protestors marched on the street, raising slogans and took out bike rallies. The police imposed a [ban on public assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_144) in Mysore. In [Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore), the [IISc](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Science) students organised silent protest in the campus in solidarity with the students of Delhi and other parts of India.[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526) In [Shimoga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shimoga), former [MLA](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minister_of_Legislative_Assembly) [K B Prasanna Kumar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._B._Prasanna_Kumar) was leading the protests near Gandhi Park in the city. The police detained him alleging that the protests were turning violent. Protests also occurred in [Bellary](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellary), [Bidar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bidar), [Gulbarga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulbarga), [Kodagu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kodagu) and [Udupi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Udupi).[\[526\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-news18_vented-526)[\[537\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minute-537) In [Raichur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raichur) protests were held after the announcement of the CAA, as the protestors had concerns that approximately 5,000 of the 20,000 Bangladeshi immigrants in the [Sindhanur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sindhanur) camp would get Indian citizenship.[\[537\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minute-537)[\[538\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-538) On 21 January more than 300,000 people join an anti-CAA protest rally at [Kalaburagi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalaburagi) in Karnataka.[\[277\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kalburgi_22_Jan-277) The rally was held 13-acre Peer Bangali ground, where people waving national flags had occupied the ground and the nearby roads. [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury), general secretary of [Communist Party of India (Marxist)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist)) and [M. Mallikarjun Kharge](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/M._Mallikarjun_Kharge), general secretary of the [All-India Congress Committee](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All-India_Congress_Committee), activists [Swamy Agnivesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swamy_Agnivesh) and former IAS officer Sasikanth Senthil gave speeches in the event. Yechury asked the people to conduct a peaceful civil disobedience movement with aim to defy the CAA, NPR, and NCR to "save the country from Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Home Minister Amit Shah".[\[277\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kalburgi_22_Jan-277) #### Bangalore [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=27) On 19 December, hundreds of protesters, including historian [Ramachandra Guha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramachandra_Guha), were detained by the [Bangalore Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore_Police) from [Town Hall](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore_Town_Hall).[\[539\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-539)[\[540\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-540) On 20 December, Karnataka High Court asked the state government to explain the prohibitions on the assembly in the state.[\[541\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-541) On 23 December, over 100,000 protesters gathered around the town hall in Bangalore.[\[542\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-542) On 4 January in Bangalore hundreds of protesters participated in a rally and accused [Modi government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modi_government) of attempts to divide India on the basis of religion, and distracting people from the issues of economic slowdown and job losses in the country.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) Respecting Section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, in force in the city until the midnight of 21 December, around 60 students from the [Indian Institute of Management Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Bangalore) came out in turns at the campus gate and left blank placards and their footwear at the campus gate, letting their footwear represent them.[\[543\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-543) As of 14 January 2020, 82 separate protest occasions had taken place in the city. The number was observed to be the highest number of protests in a month in the city's history. The protests were primarily held in Town Hall and [Freedom Park](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_Park,_Bangalore).[\[544\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-544) On 25 January, more than thousand women staged a sit in protest at Frazer Town in Bangalore for 48 hours.[\[299\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-25_January_2020-299) #### Mangalore [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=28) According to _India Today_, on 19 December seven CCTV recorded the arrival of a mob near a Mangalore police station along with a tempo carrying gunny bags full of stones. They then made an organised attempt to attack a police station, block all roads to the station, stone the police personnel and steal firearms.[\[545\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ittodaycctv-545) This was followed by the police firing on the mob, killing two people. The family of the deceased stated that the police used excessive force and should have tried to disperse the crowd instead.[\[545\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ittodaycctv-545) In [Mangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mangalore) 38 protesters from [Campus Front of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Campus_Front_of_India) who were marching towards the [Deputy commissioner](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deputy_commissioner) residence were arrested by the police arrested on charges of blocking traffic on Balmatta Road.[\[546\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Mangaluru-546) On 19 December, a curfew was imposed in Mangalore until 20 December, while protesters marched on the streets defying prohibitory orders. Two people died with gunshot wounds after police fired on the crowd.[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170)[\[175\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ToIMalayali19-175) The police in [riot gear](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riot_gear) then entered the Highland Hospital where the two people with gunshot wounds were brought. The police were accused of beating up patients and their relatives. The incident was caught on [CCTV Cameras](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/CCTV_Cameras), in which the policemen were seen banging on the hospital's [ICU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit) doors.[\[177\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto1-177)[\[176\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto2-176) Home Minister of Karnataka [Basavaraj Bommai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basavaraj_Bommai) accused the people from [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) for the violence in Mangalore.[\[547\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-547) Karnataka Police restricted the entry of people from Kerala to Mangalore at the [Thalappady](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thalappady,_Kasaragod) state border and detained more than 50 people without identity cards.[\[548\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-548) On 20 December, the mobile phones of several journalists in Mangalore (many from Kerala) were confiscated and the journalists were detained.[\[549\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-549)[\[550\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-550)[\[551\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-551) The Chief Minister of Kerala, [Pinarayi Vijayan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinarayi_Vijayan) who condemned the action as an attack on [media freedom](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_freedom) and intervened after which the journalists were released.[\[552\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-552) On 22 December, the Karnataka government announced a compensation of [₹](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee)10 [lakh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakh) (US$12,000) each to the families of the two men killed in violent protests in Mangalore on 19 December.[\[189\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-News18_Kar_10_Lakh-189) The compensation was later withheld and an enquiry was initiated on the killed men.[\[190\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IE_26_Dec_Karnataka-190) On 15 January, more than 200,000 people joined the anti-CAA protests in Mangalore, hundreds of whom came to the venue in boats carrying Indian flags. Activists Harsh Mander and Kannan Gopinathan gave speeches during the protests. An organiser said that they considered the CAA, an anti-constitutional law that will be affecting not just Muslims but all religions. The event ended peacefully with the singing of National anthem.[\[262\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Mangalore_15_Jan-262) ### Tamil Nadu [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=29) On 16 December, protests against CAA were organised by Muslim organisations and political parties in [Tirupathur district](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tirupathur_district) of [Tamil Nadu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu). Effigies of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Home Minister Amit Shah were burnt, after which more than a hundred people were detained by the police.[\[553\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Tamil_Nadu-553) Demonstrations protesting against the CAA and the attack on students in Delhi were also held by the students of Government Law College at [Katpadi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katpadi) and Government Arts College in [Tiruvannamalai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiruvannamalai).[\[553\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Tamil_Nadu-553) On 20 December, actor [Siddharth](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siddharth_(actor)), singer [T. M. Krishna](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/T._M._Krishna) and 600 others were detained for anti-CAA protests in Valluvar Kottam In Chennai.[\[554\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Mathrubhumi_20_dec-554) On 23 December [Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam) along with allied parties held a "mega rally" as an anti-CAA protest in Chennai.[\[555\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-555)[\[556\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-556) Protests were also continued to be held in various parts of Tamil Nadu including [Salem](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salem,_Tamil_Nadu) and [Krishnagiri](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnagiri).[\[557\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-557) In Chennai, eight anti-CAA activists, including five women, were arrested for drawing _[kolams](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolam)_ criticising the CAA and NRC.[\[558\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TOI-Kolam-2-558) Following their arrest, the opposition DMK officially supported the _kolam_ protest, and anti-CAA and anti-NRC _kolams_ were drawn outside the houses of its leaders and members.[\[559\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TOI-Kolam-1-559) On 16 January, police in [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai) banned all protests in the city for a period of 15 days. 5 women and 1 man (including a physically disabled person) were detained by the police for protesting against CAA.[\[267\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNM_Chennai_16_Jan-267) ### Gujarat [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=30) On 16 December, around 50 people protesting outside the [Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Ahmedabad) and [CEPT University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/CEPT_University) were detained by the [Gujarat Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat_Police).[\[560\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-560)[\[561\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-561) On 17 December, five students were arrested by the [Gujarat police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat_police) for allegedly creating a [graffiti](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graffiti) against Citizenship Act. According to the police, the students (all in their early twenties) of the [Maharaja Sayajirao University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maharaja_Sayajirao_University)'s Fine Arts department had made a graffiti that said "no CAB Modi", but instead of the letter 'o' in the phrase the students made a ' [swastika](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swastika)' sign. The graffiti was made at locations that included police headquarters, Kala Ghoda Circle, the Fatehgunj pavilion wall and the wall of a hostel near Rosary School. A police complaint was registered on 16 December for "using provocative and humiliating words to hurt sentiments of the people from one community and cause violence, and also damaging public property". The Police alleged that "They used slogans with certain symbols in their graffiti to intentionally hurt religious sentiments of a particular community and affect public peace and cause riots against members of a community. They also damaged public property." The police has already arrested five and two students who were absconding were being searched.[\[464\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_CAA_17_Dec-464) On 19 December 2019, peaceful protest march were carried out in several parts of [Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad). The peaceful protest march in [Shah-e-Alam's Roza](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shah-e-Alam%27s_Roza) area turned violent after police intervened to disperse the crowd. Police used tear gas to counter [stone pelting](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stone_pelting) while trying to disperse a crowd of 2000 protesters.[\[178\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_Gujarat_19-178) Protest rallies and strikes were also organised in several cities of Gujarat.[\[562\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-562) On 19 December 2019, videos surfaced allegedly showing protestors attacking policemen in Ahmedabad and Banaskantha.[\[563\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-563)[\[564\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-564) On 25 December 2019, many activists alleged that [Nirma University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nirma_University) in Ahmedabad tried to "intimidate" its students who took part in protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and also advised their parents to "counsel" them. The SMS sent by the university to the protesting students' parents read thus: " It has come to our knowledge that your ward was involved in protest against recent issues. The Police and Intelligence Bureau-IB have taken details of your ward from us... This is also to inform you that if your ward continues to participate in the protest, the police might create a record against him."[\[565\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-565) On 15 January 2020, a petition was filed in Gujarat High Court asking for the court's intervention to allow the petitioners to hold Anti-CAA protests in Ahmedabad. The petitioners stated that police did not grant them permission for peaceful anti-CAA protests but granted permission to 62 programmes held by the BJP to support the CAA. The petitioners said that the administration keeps denying the permission to Anti-CAA protesters and called it a violation of fundamental rights of the citizens. The Court asked the police to decide timely on the protests application.[\[263\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Wire_Guj_15_Jan-263) ### Kerala [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=31) See also: [Human chain in Kerala, 2020](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_chain_in_Kerala,_2020) Protests at [Ernakulam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernakulam), c. 23 December 2019. On 16 December, the ruling coalition, the [Left Democratic Front (LDF)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left_Democratic_Front_(Kerala)), and the opposition coalition, the [United Democratric Front (UDF)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Democratic_Front_(Kerala)), organised a joint [hunger strike](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_strike) in the [Thiruvananthapuram](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thiruvananthapuram) Martyr's Square. Chief Minister [Pinarayi Vijayan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinarayi_Vijayan) stated that Kerala will "stand together to fight against the evil designs of the Modi government undermining the secular credentials of India", terming the Citizens Amendment Act "anti-constitutional and anti-people". Leader of the Opposition [Ramesh Chennithala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramesh_Chennithala) observed that another struggle for Independence is required to save the constitution from " [fascist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascist) forces".[\[566\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-India_Today_Kerala-566) On 17 December, A dawn-to-dusk hartal (shutdown) was observed in Kerala by [Welfare Party of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_Party_of_India), [Bahujan Samaj Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bahujan_Samaj_Party), [Social Democratic Party of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_India) and other 30 organisation against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the police violence against students at various universities across the country, in relation to anti-CAA protests.[\[165\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITStoned-165)[\[166\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TimesNowKeralaHartal-166) The Kerala police detained 233 people in connection with the hartal, including 55 people in Ernakulam, 51 in Thrissur and 35 in Idukki. In Palakkad 21 people have been detained, while 13 were detained in Kannur, 12 in Kottayam and 8 in Wayanad.[\[567\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-567) On 23 December, multiple protests in Kochi was organised and took place.[\[568\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-568) People's long march, which started from [Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_Stadium_(Kochi)) premises and ended near [Cochin Shipyard](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cochin_Shipyard). Cultural activists led another march from the Gandhi Square to Vasco De Gama Square at [Fort Kochi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Kochi).[\[569\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-569) Another march led by CPI state secretary [Kanam Rajendran](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanam_Rajendran) was also held at the same time started from [Kalamassery](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalamassery) and ended in Rajendra Maidanam.[\[570\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-570)[\[571\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-571) On 24 December, [Differently-abled](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disability) Come together against CAA and NRC at [Marine Drive, Kochi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_Drive,_Kochi).[\[572\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-572) On 28 December, several delegates attending the [Indian History Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_History_Congress) held at [Kannur University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kannur_University) protested during Kerala Governor [Arif Mohammad Khan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arif_Mohammad_Khan)'s speech. Some of them were detained by police, but were later released following an intervention by Kannur University.[\[573\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Kannur_Unv_protest-573) On 31 December, [Kerala Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_Legislative_Assembly) passed a resolution demanding scrapping of the Act.[\[574\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-574) On 1 January 2020 in [Kochi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kochi), around half a million assembled in peaceful rally to protest against the CAA-NRC, held between [Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru_Stadium,_Kochi) and [Marine Drive](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marine_Drive,_Kochi).[\[575\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-575)[\[576\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-576) On 14 January, the [Kerala government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala_government) approached Supreme Court to challenge the CAA under section 131 of the constitution and becomes the first state to do so. The article 131 of the Indian constitution provides Supreme Court the power to decide the disputes between the states and the Government of India.[\[257\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Kerala_CAA_14_Jan-257)[\[258\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-14_Jan-258) The Kerala government in its petition called the act "a violation of India's secular constitution" and accused the Indian government of dividing the country among religious lines. Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan said, "Kerala will always remain in the forefront of this fight to protect the Indian constitution and the fundamental rights of its citizens,". Vijayan added that Kerala will save the rights of the citizens from the unconstitutional CAA by fighting against it using constitutional methods.[\[577\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_14_Jan-577) On 26 January, to protest against the CAA and the proposed NRC the [Left Democratic Front](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left_Democratic_Front_(Kerala)) led by the Communist Party of India (Marxist) had organised the human chain. The chain was formed by approximately 6 to 7 million people and extended for a distance of 620 kilometres from [Kasaragod](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kasaragod_district) to [Kaliyikkavila](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaliyakkavilai).[\[578\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-578)[\[304\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-:1-304) ### Telangana [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=32) Million March, Hyderabad On 16 December, thousands of students from major institutes in [Hyderabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad) such as [University of Hyderabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Hyderabad), [Osmania University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osmania_University) and [MANU University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maulana_Azad_National_Urdu_University) participated in protests, demanding a rollback of the CAA.[\[579\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-579) On 21 December, numerous protests took place across Hyderabad organised by students, NGOs and various political parties. The [Hyderabad Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad_Police) stated that the protests remained peaceful. Protesters demanded Chief Minister [K. Chandrashekar Rao](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/K._Chandrashekar_Rao), whose party [Telangana Rashtra Samithi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telangana_Rashtra_Samithi) had voted against the bill in parliament, to end his silence with respect to the CAA.[\[580\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-580) By 23 December, it was reported that protests had spread to smaller towns, including Nizamabad.[\[581\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-581) On 4 January, more than 100,000 protesters attended the protest march named "Million March" in Hyderabad.[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) The protesters displayed placards with slogans saying "Withdraw CAA immediately," and "India's only religion in secularism".[\[235\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters_4_Jan_Hyd-235) ### Bihar [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=33) On 17 December, posters describing Bihar Chief Minister [Nitish Kumar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitish_Kumar) as "missing" were erected as a form of protest in Patna. Nitish Kumar had been criticised for his silence over the CAA. while his party, [Janata Dal (United)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)), had supported the bill in both the Houses of Parliament as part of the alliance with the [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party). The JD(U) party strategist [Prashant Kishor](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prashant_Kishor), party spokesperson [Pavan Verma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pavan_Varma) and MLC [Gulam Rasool Balyawi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulam_Rasool_Balyawi) had voiced dissatisfaction over the party's stance on CAA.[\[582\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-582)[\[583\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-583) On 19 December, Nitish Kumar declared that the NRC will not be implemented in the state, becoming the first major [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) ally to reject the controversial measure.[\[584\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-584) On 19 December, a [bandh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bandh) was called by [communist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism) parties in [Bihar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar), supported by a number of small parties, where protesters blocked rail and road traffic in protest against CAA and the proposed countrywide implementation of NRC.[\[585\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-585)[\[425\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HBL-425) On Saturday, 21 December, a "Bihar bandh" was called by the [Rashtriya Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtriya_Janata_Dal) (RJD), where bandh supporters reportedly blocked railway tracks in [Araria](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Araria_district) and [East Champaran](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Champaran_district) districts. In [Nawada](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nawada), bandh supporters demonstrated on [National Highway 31](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Highway_31_(India)) where wheels were burned on the road and the movement of vehicles was disrupted, while in [Vaishali](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaishali_district), the highway was blocked with the help of buffaloes. In Patna, hundreds of party supporters with lathis entered the railway stations and bus stations with party flags, but were repulsed by policemen. At [Darbhanga](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darbhanga), RJD workers and supporters protested bare chest, sloganeering against Bihar chief minister Nitish Kumar and central government.[\[586\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-586)[\[587\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-587) During a protest at [Phulwari Sharif](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phulwari_Sharif) near Patna, some of the miscreants started pelting stones and a clash broke out between protesters and the supporters of the Act. A nearby temple and a cemetery were damaged in the clash. Eyewitnesses said police had used tear gas and water cannon to disperse the people. Police said that people of Hindu community fired bullets that injured nine Muslim men.[\[588\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-588) During the stampede, an eighteen years old teenage protester Amir Hanzla ran towards the lanes of Sangat Mohalla, a neighbourhood that was a hub of [RSS-affiliated](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/RSS-affiliated) right wing Hindutva members.[\[589\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-589) His dead body was found a week after he was allegedly murdered by the [Hindutva](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindutva) extremists.[\[590\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-590) Police arrested six people accused in the case who belonged to Hindu Putra Sangathan, a Hindutva group. All of the suspects confessed their crimes and police is also investigating 18 other organisations related to this extremist group.[\[591\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-591) ### Maharashtra [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=34) On 19 December, different NGOs and college students, backed by [Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress), [Nationalist Congress Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nationalist_Congress_Party) and [Left Democratic Front](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left_Democratic_Front_(Maharashtra)) parties, jointly formed a front with the name " _Hum Bharat Ke Log_" and held a protest at the August Kranti Maidan.[\[592\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-592)[\[170\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_Live_19-170) In Mumbai, several actors including [Farhan Akhtar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farhan_Akhtar), [Swara Bhaskar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swara_Bhaskar), [Huma Qureshi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huma_Qureshi), [Raj Babbar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raj_Babbar), [Sushant Singh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sushant_Singh), [Javed Jaffrey](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Javed_Jaffrey), [Aditi Rao Hydari](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aditi_Rao_Hydari), [Parvathy
