title: Trump Tariffs: Impact on Indian Economy & Global Trade
full_text: [![Niti Shastra](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/w_80,h_80,c_fill,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep,g_auto/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F67389fc5-67d3-4725-9a0c-25f3ea090cd8_256x256.png)](https://nitishastra.substack.com/) # [Niti Shastra](https://nitishastra.substack.com/) SubscribeSign in # Trump Tariffs: Impact on Indian Economy & Global Trade [![Navroop Singh's avatar](fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F4938a2a0-5ea2-4567-85d8-89d334d22931_427x434.jpeg)](https://substack.com/@navroopsingh)[![Himja Parekh's avatar](fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F0ff2fe08-60ba-4b39-957b-2cafc413ffb3_144x144.png)](https://substack.com/@himjap) [Navroop Singh](https://substack.com/@navroopsingh) and [Himja Parekh](https://substack.com/@himjap) Apr 06, 2025 4 2 [Share](javascript:void(0)) [![](fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fbddf2af0-71c8-4da4-b51e-bc6301aac12d_2731x4096.png)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fbddf2af0-71c8-4da4-b51e-bc6301aac12d_2731x4096.png) ### **Introduction** In the past decade, global trade dynamics have undergone seismic shifts, none more pronounced than during the presidency of Donald J. Trump. With his administration’s fervent embrace of economic nationalism and an "America First" doctrine, Trump disrupted long-standing trade norms, sparking a wave of tariff wars that has reverberated through every corner of the global economy. Though much of the media focus is rightly placed on the bruising economic standoff between the United States and China, India Asia’s third-largest economy is not immune to the aftershocks. The U.S.-China trade war creates opportunities for India in certain supply chains, but it also exposes vulnerabilities, particularly as the Trump administration turned its gaze toward India’s growing trade surplus with the U.S. The imposition of significant tariffs on Indian exports, culminating in a sweeping 26% blanket tariff across multiple sectors in 2025, raises fundamental questions about India's role in global trade. Is India prepared to step into the breach as a neutral manufacturing alternative to China? Could it shield its vulnerable sectors while still leveraging its demographic and production strengths? And, perhaps most critically, how would this barrage of tariffs shape the trajectory of India’s economic growth, labor markets, and diplomatic positioning? This blog explores in depth the multifaceted impact of Trump-era tariffs and the broader U.S.-China trade war on the Indian economy and the global economy at large. It moves sector by sector examining information technology, pharmaceuticals, gems and jewellery, agriculture, electronics, and automobile components while also considering the macroeconomic and geopolitical consequences. What emerges is a complex, at times contradictory, narrative: one of challenges and constraints but also of adaptation and opportunity. The last portion of blog goes on to discuss the Chinese retaliation to American trade tariffs and how India, Russia and the world could navigate these choppy waters of trade wars. ### **Trump’s Tariff Policies and Global Trade Disruption** Donald Trump's approach to international trade marks a significant departure from the multilateralism that had defined U.S. economic policy since World War II. In its place emerged a unilateral, punitive model rooted in protectionism. Central to this strategy are tariffs, imposed under various legal pretexts ranging from national security to the invocation of Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974. These actions targeted not only China, with which the U.S. had the most visible confrontation, but also long-standing allies and trade partners, including the European Union, Canada, Mexico, and notably, India. India finds itself on Trump’s radar for two main reasons. First, the U.S. consistently ran a trade deficit with India, which reached nearly $24 billion at its peak in 2018. Second, Washington increasingly viewed India’s protectionist policies including high tariffs on American goods and complex regulatory barriers as incompatible with fair trade practices. In retaliation, the Trump administration revoked India’s preferential trade status under the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) in 2019, stripping benefits from over $5.6 billion worth of Indian exports. This revocation was followed by a series of tariff escalations. In response, India imposed retaliatory tariffs on 28 U.S. products, including almonds, apples, and walnuts. While the tit-for-tat measures remained relatively contained through the end of Trump’s first term, the return of Trump-era trade policies in the form of a renewed push in 2025 to reestablish tariff barriers saw a more aggressive posture. A sweeping 26% tariff on a range of Indian imports has been levied, justified on grounds of "reciprocity" and the perceived need to counterbalance India's own trade barriers. Though the direct numerical impact of these tariffs varied by sector, the cumulative psychological and financial blow is profound. Indian exporters, already grappling with a complex global trade environment post-COVID and amid increasing competition from Southeast Asian economies, are now being forced to reconsider their market strategies. Some are seeking to pivot toward Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, while others have doubled down on compliance and lobbying in Washington, hoping for sectoral exemptions. But across the board, there is a recognition that India’s days of quasi-free access to the U.S. market were over. This dramatic shift in policy direction, combined with the concurrent U.S.-China standoff, creates a new matrix of challenges and opportunities for India. On the one hand, companies sought to "de-risk" their supply chains by moving out of China, and India appeared as an attractive alternative. On the other hand, the aggressive U.S. posture toward multiple trading partners complicated efforts to present India as a stable and reliable destination for global manufacturing. The rest of this blog will explore how this turbulent geopolitical trade environment might unfold on the ground in India sector by sector, policy by policy and how Indian industry, government, could respond to a rapidly changing global economic order. ### **Information Technology Services: Indirect Exposure and Demand Slowdown** India’s information technology (IT) services sector has long stood as a pillar of the nation’s export economy. With marquee companies like Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), Infosys, Wipro, and HCL Technologies delivering software development, business process outsourcing (BPO), and consulting services across global markets particularly the United States the sector has become a symbol of India’s integration into the global knowledge economy. In 2023, over 60% of Indian IT services exports were directed to North America, making the region not just a growth engine but a lifeline. Despite the 2025 Trump-era tariffs are not directly targeting IT services which are often intangible and not subject to customs duties the sector found itself indirectly caught in the economic crossfire. The broader uncertainty and potential economic slowdown triggered by protectionist trade measures in the U.S. has a chilling effect on discretionary IT spending. Key client industries in the U.S. particularly manufacturing, retail, automotive, and financial services have begun tightening budgets in anticipation of slower growth and greater regulatory volatility. This belt-tightening will have a direct impact on Indian IT firms. Deal cycles will lengthen; contract values might shrink with renewals slowing as American companies reassess their digital transformation roadmaps. Even though the need for cloud migration, cybersecurity, and AI integration remains strong, many clients would hesitate to commit to long-term engagements. Indian IT companies, highly sensitive to these ebbs and flows, will be forced to adjust revenue guidance downward. Adding to the complexity is the resurgence of debate within U.S. political circles about outsourcing and job offshoring. Under the broader nationalist economic agenda, the Trump-aligned rhetoric has once again questioned the logic of American companies depending on foreign IT service providers for core operational functions. Though these debates did not immediately result in legislation, they create a reputational risk for Indian firms and prompt some U.S.-based clients to consider “onshoring” a portion of their operations. This, in turn, could place pressure on Indian companies to expand their footprint in the U.S. by hiring locally or acquiring American firms moves that typically come with higher costs. Yet, amid the challenges, some silver linings emerge. The same de-risking logic that pushed American companies to diversify away from Chinese hardware providers extended albeit subtly to software and digital services. Indian firms that have invested early in building local delivery centers in the U.S. can find themselves better positioned to win government contracts and industry-specific deals, particularly in healthcare and federal services. The evolving cybersecurity landscape, shaped by growing concerns over Chinese technology espionage, can also help Indian companies portray themselves as neutral, reliable partners. Nevertheless, the net impact of the trade war and tariff environment is a slowdown in India’s IT growth trajectory. Hiring is likely to be curtailed across major firms, with campus placements reduced in volume and deferred in schedule. The IT sector may continue to underperform broader markets during the period, reflecting investor skepticism about near-term margins and growth. Startups in the SaaS space, particularly those dependent on U.S. small- and medium-sized business clients, are also experiencing funding constraints as venture capital became wary of exposure to geopolitical risk. In summary, while not a direct casualty of the Trump-era tariffs, India’s IT services sector is nonetheless ensnared in the ripple effects of a decelerating and increasingly protectionist U.S. economy. The looming recession in American economy & the adoption of Artificial Intelligence is further likely to hit deal wins and profit margins of Indian IT firms as discretionary spends will slow down. The sector’s resilience and adaptability so far has helped mitigate the worst of the damage, but its overreliance on the North American market is once again laid bare. The episode serves as both a warning and a catalyst for diversification geographically, sectorally, and technologically. ### **Pharmaceuticals: The Resilient Outlier in the Storm** Among all the sectors caught in the web of shifting trade policies and tariff battles, India’s pharmaceutical industry has emerged as a rare beacon of resilience and in some ways, strategic indispensability. As one of the world’s largest suppliers of generic drugs and active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs), India has long been referred to as the "pharmacy of the developing world." But more crucially, it is also a major supplier of affordable medicines to the United States. With over $9 billion in annual pharmaceutical exports to the U.S., India’s role in sustaining the American healthcare system is profound, and arguably irreplaceable in the short-to-medium term. This strategic relevance proved vital when the Trump administration, despite its sweeping tariff agenda in 2025, consciously chose to exempt pharmaceutical imports from India. The rationale behind this exemption was as much about domestic U.S. politics as it was about public health. Rising healthcare costs had become a flashpoint in American domestic discourse, and the availability of low-cost generics was viewed as essential to controlling insurance premiums and out-of-pocket expenses for millions of Americans. In a nation where prescription drug prices often rank among the highest in the world, the supply of cost-effective Indian medicines played a crucial stabilizing role. This exemption came as a relief to Indian pharmaceutical giants which rely heavily on the U.S. market for both revenue and regulatory prestige. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) remains the gold standard for drug approvals globally, and success in the U.S. market often unlocks access to other lucrative territories. Maintaining uninterrupted trade relations with the U.S. ensures that Indian firms could continue with their product launches, including complex generics and biosimilars, even amid a fractious global trade atmosphere. However, the pharmaceutical sector is not entirely insulated from broader headwinds. Increased scrutiny from the FDA over manufacturing practices, ongoing concerns about data integrity, and periodic import bans on specific production units continued to cast a shadow. Moreover, while the sector is so far spared from tariffs, it faced indirect pressure from the depreciation of the Indian rupee, rising raw material costs especially APIs sourced from China and logistical disruptions due to global shipping uncertainties. An interesting twist during the tariff escalation is the quiet encouragement within the U.S. policy community to "onshore" some critical medicine production capabilities. Although this movement was primarily directed at reducing dependency on China, it also raised questions about over-reliance on India for certain life-saving drugs. Consequently, some Indian pharmaceutical firms have begun exploring joint ventures and acquisitions in the United States to build a more embedded presence in the American pharmaceutical ecosystem. These ventures served both as hedges against potential future protectionism and as a way to reduce political risk exposure. The pandemic experience also has a lingering effect on how pharmaceutical supply chains are viewed. Having played a central role in global COVID-19 vaccine production and distribution, Indian pharmaceutical companies enjoyed a degree of diplomatic goodwill that proved useful during this trade conflict. Indian vaccine diplomacy, combined with active participation in global health initiatives, helped bolster the sector's reputation as a force for global good rather than just another profit-seeking exporter. Domestically, the sector saw increased investment and policy support from the Indian government under the Production Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme, which aimed to make India more self-reliant in API manufacturing and high-end formulations. These efforts aligned with a larger vision of building resilience in critical sectors and reducing strategic dependencies. In totality, the pharmaceutical industry stands out as a resilient outlier in a period marked by volatility and protectionism. While other export-oriented sectors scramble to adapt to new tariff realities, pharma remained steady, shielded by its strategic value and deep entrenchment in global healthcare networks. Yet, even this seeming immunity came with a quiet warning: India’s strength in pharmaceuticals must be underpinned by constant vigilance in quality control, supply chain robustness, and strategic global outreach. The sector's ability to remain tariff-exempt may not be permanent as President Trump has already threatened to impose Pharma tariffs in coming days which could substantially hit Indian generic pharma manufacturers however innovator & contract manufacturing like CDMO pharma having base in US & Europe may not be that impacted as API supply chains might diversify to India from China. ### **Gems and Jewellery: A Sector Under Siege** In stark contrast to the pharmaceutical industry’s relative immunity, India’s gems and jewellery sector finds itself squarely in the crosshairs of the Trump-era tariff escalation. Long a crown jewel of India’s export economy, this sector has deep cultural, economic, and employment linkages across the country. From the diamond polishing workshops of Surat to the goldsmith clusters in Tamil Nadu and the jewellery design hubs of Mumbai, the industry employs over five million people, directly and indirectly. The United States, meanwhile, stands as its largest export destination, accounting for nearly 40% of the sector’s international sales. The imposition of a steep 26% tariff up from effectively zero in many cases on jewellery and polished stones in 2025 is a body blow. Unlike pharmaceuticals, where strategic considerations could override commercial logic, the gems and jewellery sector offered no such buffer. To the Trump administration, luxury goods like diamonds, gold jewellery, and precious ornaments are fair game symbols of elite consumption, low in political cost and high in symbolic value when framed as a defense of American industry and artisanship. This could result in dramatic contraction in Indian exports to the U.S. almost overnight as the tariffs go in effect on 9th April 2025. For Indian exporters, the implications are immediate and far-reaching. Existing contracts could be renegotiated or even cancelled. Retailers in the U.S., facing significantly higher landing costs may turn to domestic suppliers or explore alternative markets in Thailand and Turkey. Indian exporters, especially small and medium enterprises (SMEs) without the financial cushion or global footprint to absorb such shocks, will be forced to furlough workers, delay shipments, and slash production. The city of Surat, which processes nine out of every ten diamonds sold globally, could possibly report a huge drop in orders within the first quarter following the tariff hike. Beyond the sheer scale of financial loss, the emotional and psychological toll on the industry could be profound. For decades, India has cultivated a reputation for excellence, affordability, and reliability in the global gemstone trade. That credibility takes a hit not because of a lapse in quality or service, but due to geopolitical crossfire. Many industry stakeholders feel blindsided, arguing that the U.S. failed to appreciate the interdependencies at play. After all, the gems and jewellery trade wasn’t just about finished products. It was about deep supply chains, craftsmanship, and a legacy of bilateral economic engagement that transcended borders. Efforts by the Indian government to lobby for a reduction in tariffs through backchannel diplomacy and formal trade talks so far have yielded little success in the short term though a Bilateral Trade Agreement could be made in medium term. While conversations have continued under the auspices of broader U.S.-India trade negotiations, the Trump administration remained adamant while going ahead on reciprocal tariffs without significant reciprocal concessions something New Delhi was unwilling to provide amid domestic political sensitivities around gold import duties and the broader current account balance. To adapt, Indian exporters should look to diversify their markets. Efforts must be intensified to increase sales to the UAE, Hong Kong, and the EU. The India-UAE Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA), which offered duty-free access for certain jewellery products, could become a vital fallback. Digital platforms can also be embraced more aggressively, with some jewellers launching direct-to-consumer channels targeting the Indian diaspora and other non-U.S. audiences. But the damage in the U.S. market remains undeniable. Major brands that once sourced heavily from India should start exploring alternative supply chains to hedge against geopolitical risk. Even within India, investment in the sector can slow down, as uncertainty over export prospects made financing harder to obtain and discouraged risk-taking. In policy circles, the tariff crisis renewed debates over the need for long-term structural reforms in the gems and jewellery sector. India must go for further value addition with stricter traceability standards to meet international norms, and more robust branding of Indian-made jewellery in global markets. Some even suggest exploring vertical integration models, akin to what De Beers and Tiffany have championed, to insulate against such shocks in the future. Ultimately, the Trump-era tariffs serve as a brutal reminder of the vulnerability of non-strategic, high-value export sectors to sudden geopolitical shifts. For India’s gems and jewellery industry, the path forward lay in adaptation but also in hard-nosed diplomacy, market diversification, and a fundamental rethinking of the sector’s dependence on any single nation, no matter how lucrative. ### **Agriculture: Mixed Fortunes and Strategic Positioning** Agriculture has always occupied a uniquely sensitive space in India’s economic and political landscape. It remains the primary source of livelihood for nearly half the population and contributes significantly to export revenues through commodities like rice, tea, spices, seafood, and cotton. As the U.S. ramps up its tariff wars, global agricultural trade flows can be disrupted, creating a patchwork of risks and opportunities for India. While the sector is not directly hit by the 2025 Trump tariffs to the extent of others many key agricultural exports remained exempt the ripple effects are nonetheless complex and multifaceted. India is one of the largest exporters of Sea Food and Basmati Rice to USA with states like Kerala, Andhra Pradesh and Gujarat playing a critical role in seafood exports. The U.S. remains one of the largest importers of Indian shrimp, and demand has held up steady despite rising prices and logistical challenges. Similarly, India’s dominance in the basmati rice market remains unchallenged due to strong diaspora demand and the high entry barriers for competing products. But even as specific commodities dodged tariff penalties, broader trade friction can lead to increase inspections, slower port clearances, and tightening of quality and phytosanitary regulations at the U.S. border. These procedural bottlenecks, although not officially part of any tariff schedule, introduce new non-tariff barriers that effectively increase the cost and complexity of doing business. Smaller exporters, lacking compliance infrastructure, may struggle disproportionately. At the same time, India finds itself presented with strategic opportunities, particularly in light of the U.S.-China trade decoupling. As the Trump administration sharply curtails agricultural imports from China most notably soybeans, garlic, and certain processed foods zU.S. importers could explore alternative sourcing markets. India, with its vast agricultural diversity and relatively low production costs, can emerge as a potential replacement. Though it can’t fill China’s massive export shoes overnight, Indian suppliers of niche agricultural goods can see a spike in inquiries from U.S. distributors looking to diversify their procurement sources. However, seizing these opportunities wasn’t always straightforward. Structural issues within Indian agriculture like fragmented land holdings, inconsistent supply chains, inadequate cold storage, and fluctuating quality standards posed barriers to rapid scale-up. Moreover, price volatility, driven by weak monsoons and input cost inflation, make Indian commodities less predictable from the perspective of foreign buyers. These challenges underscore the need for deeper reform, investment, and modernization in the sector, if India were to meaningfully capitalize on its comparative advantages. Meanwhile, domestic political sensitivities added another layer of complexity. In the aftermath of the farmers’ protests that had swept the country in previous years, the Indian government is very cautious about appearing to prioritize exports over local food security. This has tempered its willingness to enter into concessions with the United States that could benefit exporters but risk domestic backlash especially on politically sensitive items like dairy and wheat and the issues of Farmer subsidies, MSP. Nevertheless, India should use this opportunity to bring the much need agricultural reforms like fostering new public-private partnerships to develop farmer-producer organizations (FPOs) capable of engaging directly with foreign buyers, bypassing layers of middlemen and improving both income distribution and traceability. India should also look to setting up cold storage supply chains and improve logistical bottlenecks for Indian Agro products to be exported globally. This can be a part of a broader vision to integrate Indian agriculture more closely with global value chains while still retaining a core commitment to food sovereignty and rural employment. ### **Electronics and Hardware: Between the Tariff Fire and the China Factor** India's electronics and hardware sector finds itself in a curious position amid the intensifying U.S.-China trade war and the subsequent imposition of tariffs on Indian imports. On one hand, this is a sector that stood to gain significantly from the U.S. desire to "decouple" from Chinese electronics and semiconductors. On the other, the sudden imposition of a sweeping 26% tariff on Indian electronic goods in April 2025 has threatened to derail much of the progress made in recent years. For a country still in the nascent stages of developing a globally competitive electronics export industry, the situation demands a swift and strategic recalibration. To understand the stakes, one must appreciate the evolution of India’s electronics sector. For decades, India was viewed primarily as a consumer, rather than a manufacturer, of electronic products. However, under the “Make in India” initiative and, more recently, the Production Linked Incentive (PLI) schemes, significant efforts have been made to transform the country into a manufacturing hub. Large players like Foxconn, Pegatron, and Samsung have set up assembly units for smartphones, consumer electronics, and semiconductor packaging, particularly in Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, and Uttar Pradesh. These developments led to a sharp rise in India’s electronics exports from under $10 billion in the early 2010s to over $23 billion by 2024. The U.S. had emerged as a key export market, especially for consumer electronics, chargers, LED products, and IT hardware components. The hope was that India could step into the vacuum left by Chinese firms like Huawei and ZTE, which faced intense scrutiny and sanctions in the U.S. on national security grounds. However, the Trump administration’s broad-brush approach to tariffs has disrupted this strategic alignment. The 26% tariff imposed on a wide swath of Indian electronics products even as Chinese products were subjected to even higher duties throw a wrench into the equation. While India retains a relative cost advantage over China, the new tariff regime has dulled its competitive edge. American importers now have to choose between paying high tariffs on Chinese goods or slightly less onerous ones on Indian products. For many, the calculus doesn’t justify a rapid supply chain overhaul. Instead of aggressively shifting to India, several U.S. companies may adopt a wait-and-watch approach, or divert some of their sourcing to other low tariff zone like Australia, New Zealand, UK, Brazil, Argentina, Saudi Arabia or even UAE, which enjoy more favourable trade terms with USA. Indian electronic manufacturing industry has already sounded alarm of losing out business to low tariffs zones compared to India. Within India, the response is cautious and mixed. Larger firms with global exposure could explore the option of expanding manufacturing footprints in countries with preferential trade access to the U.S., such as Latin America or Europe. This "geo-sourcing" strategy could allow them to skirt around tariff walls while maintaining their supply chain linkages with India. Smaller manufacturers, however, will be left scrambling with lack of capital, logistical muscle to pivot internationally forcing them to cut production, lay off workers, or shift focus to the domestic markets. The broader policy response from New Delhi can be twofold. First, a renewed push for trade diplomacy aimed at carving out sectoral exemptions or negotiating a digital and electronics-specific agreement under the broader U.S.-India trade dialogue. Indian officials can emphasize that penalizing Indian electronics is counterproductive to U.S. goals of building a trusted and democratic global supply chain. While these arguments may resonate with certain quarters in Washington, they could fail to produce immediate policy relief forcing international suppliers to pivot to another low tariff jurisdiction. Second, the Indian government can double down on domestic reforms like giving additional incentives can be offered to companies investing in component manufacturing, not just final assembly. Semiconductor policy should be given a major push, with subsidies for fab plants and chip design firms. Special Economic Zones (SEZs) should be repurposed to serve as electronics export hubs, and customs procedures be streamlined to reduce turnaround times for high-value shipments. These moves can offer a long-term vision to build electronics manufacturing depth that could weather future geopolitical turbulence. Despite the tariff’s setbacks, India’s strategic position in global electronics should continue to improve albeit incrementally. Some American and European firms, wary of deep exposure to China, may begin limited sourcing from Indian partners. Indian contract manufacturers could also start moving up the value chain, offering design, prototyping, and embedded systems integration areas where price sensitivity is lower and expertise matters more. In the high-margin segments like medical devices and aerospace electronics, Indian industry can carve out a niche. Nevertheless, the tariff-induced shock has made one thing abundantly clear: India’s electronics sector is extremely too vulnerable to policy swings in major markets, especially the United States. It lacks both the scale and insulation to thrive in a protectionist environment without significant diplomatic support. For policymakers and industry leaders alike, this is a moment of reckoning an inflection point that underscores the need for strategic self-sufficiency, diversified markets, and robust global partnerships built not merely on price competitiveness but on trust, technology, and long-term value. ### **Automobile Components: Collateral Damage and Strategic Rethinking** India's automobile components industry, though less flashy than its IT or pharmaceutical counterparts, has quietly emerged as a key pillar of the country's export landscape. With over $19 billion in exports as of 2024, the sector supplies a diverse array of parts to global auto giants, including Ford, General Motors, Volkswagen, and Toyota. The United States, as one of the largest automotive markets in the world, accounts for a significant share of these exports particularly in engine components, braking systems, transmission parts, and electrical assemblies. The 2025 imposition of a 25% tariff on Indian auto parts by the Trump administration struck the industry at a vulnerable moment. Just as it was beginning to recover from pandemic-era supply chain shocks and semiconductor shortages, the renewed wave of protectionism threatens to undercut its competitiveness in the North American market. While India is not the primary target Trump’s policy is broadly aimed at reshoring U.S. auto manufacturing and countering China’s dominance, however the collateral damage to Indian suppliers is undeniable. For Indian manufacturers, the tariff effectively raises the landing cost of their products, narrowing the price gap that had made them attractive to American auto assemblers in the first place. As a result, many U.S.-based companies can reevaluate their supplier portfolios. Some can look toward Mexico, benefiting from the USMCA (United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement), while others may consider closer-to-home sourcing options despite higher base prices. The volume of purchase orders from Indian firms could dip, slowing down long-term contract negotiations considerably. Largely, globally integrated Indian firms are better equipped to weather the storm. Many of them already have production facilities in the U.S. or Europe, allowing them to shift some manufacturing offshore to bypass the tariff wall. But smaller firms, which make up the backbone of India’s auto components ecosystem, lack this flexibility. For them, the tariff meant margin erosion, declining order books, and an urgent need to refocus on other markets or scale down exports altogether. This sudden realignment has forced a broader introspection within the industry. The dependence on a single large export market like the U.S. had always been a strategic risk, but the tariff war turned it into an operational crisis. Many firms can look to investing in the ASEAN region, trying to tap into the emerging electric vehicle (EV) supply chains in Southeast Asia. Others can turn toward Europe, where regulatory demands were higher but tariff environments more stable. Domestic demand, bolstered by India's own automotive growth, provided a partial cushion but could not fully compensate for lost U.S. business. In response, the Indian government can offer modest support measures like export credit guarantees be extended, and schemes under the Atmanirbhar Bharat initiative to be expanded to include more auto component clusters. However, these could be temporary fixes and what is needed, is a long-term vision to boost high-tech manufacturing, reduce reliance on basic components exports, and transition into Tier 1 and Tier 2 supplier roles in global EV and autonomous vehicle ecosystems. To this end, several industry leaders should explore strategic partnerships with global automotive technology firms. The focus should shift from just volume-driven exports to value-added components like battery management systems, EV inverters, and advanced driver-assistance systems (ADAS). R&D budgets should be reallocated toward innovation, and joint ventures need to be proposed to develop proprietary technologies rather than simply serve as low-cost suppliers. The broader aim should be to make Indian firms indispensable within global value chains less replaceable, and more aligned with the future of mobility. In the final analysis, the automobile components sector can bear the brunt of being peripheral to the strategic calculations of both Washington and New Delhi. It lacks the national security implications of pharmaceuticals or the geo-digital relevance of IT. Yet it is foundational to jobs, regional development, and industrial modernization in India. The Trump-era tariffs may have weakened its U.S.-bound prospects temporarily, but they also catalyzed a strategic rethink, a pivot from volume to value, and from dependence to diversification. Whether that transformation can be sustained will depend on how quickly the industry can adapt to an automotive future that is increasingly electric, connected, and protectionist. ### **Trump Tariffs knitting Indian Textile Sector** The recent imposition of retaliatory tariffs by the United States, specifically a 26% levy on Indian imports, is creating ripples across India's textile sector. While on the surface this might appear punitive, a deeper look reveals that India is relatively better positioned compared to its regional competitors. China now faces a 54% tariff on textile exports to the U.S., Bangladesh 37%, and Vietnam a steep 46%. This disparity offers Indian exporters a significant pricing advantage in the American market, especially for mid-range and mass-market apparel categories where cost competitiveness is crucial. For Indian textile manufacturers and exporters, this development presents a timely opportunity to capture greater market share in the United States. U.S. buyers, faced with shrinking margins due to increased input costs, are actively looking to shift sourcing away from China and other higher-tariff countries. Indian firms, particularly those in Tamil Nadu, Gujarat, and Maharashtra, are reporting a surge in inquiries and new contracts. The sector, already benefiting from the China+1 strategy and diversification in global supply chains, now has an additional tailwind to boost exports, particularly in segments like cotton garments, home textiles, and woven fabrics. However, challenges remain. Despite the tariff advantage, India’s textile sector grapples with structural inefficiencies such as outdated machinery, high power tariffs, and labour laws that limit flexibility. Additionally, competition from duty-free countries like those under the U.S. Generalized System of Preferences (GSP), though reduced in scope, still exists. Indian exporters must also contend with non-tariff barriers such as quality certifications, sustainability mandates, and tighter scrutiny on labour practices all of which are becoming standard expectations from U.S. and European buyers. To fully capitalize on this geopolitical and trade shift, the Indian government must enact supportive policies that enhance production efficiency and global competitiveness. Expanding textile parks, simplifying compliance under labour codes, and offering targeted subsidies or incentives for green manufacturing can help Indian exporters convert this short-term advantage into long-term dominance. Furthermore, by improving container logistics and port infrastructure, India can reduce lead times and better compete with East Asian peers. If leveraged wisely, the current tariff landscape could be a transformative moment for India’s textile industry. Further if countries like Vietnam engage in diplomacy and opt for zero tariff trade pacts with USA it could lead to that opportunity dwindling away for the textile sector. ### **Macroeconomic Implications: Growth, Inflation, and Policy Dilemmas** The cumulative effect of Trump-era tariffs on India’s macroeconomic landscape extends well beyond individual sectors. Though the trade tensions are primarily cast as bilateral skirmishes between governments and industries, their true reverberations are felt at the national level in GDP projections, inflation rates, investor sentiment, and policy maneuverability. The U.S. decision to impose a flat 26% tariff on a broad spectrum of Indian exports comes at a particularly fragile moment for the Indian economy, which was already navigating a complex terrain of post-pandemic recovery, global supply chain realignments, and rising energy costs amid a slowdown and a liquidity crunch overall in the economy. Early estimates from financial institutions and think tanks suggested that the tariffs could shave off anywhere between 20 to 40 basis points from India’s GDP growth in the 2025–26 fiscal year. Though this figure may seem modest on the surface, the real pain lay in its concentration, certain export-heavy states, districts, and employment clusters would bear the brunt of the impact. Exporters might face rising inventories, tighter cash flows, and delayed payments from international buyers who are themselves are grappling with the uncertainty of a volatile tariff regime. These microeconomic stresses can quickly feed into the broader economic narrative, dampening the optimism that had been building around India's potential to serve as a "China plus one" manufacturing alternative. At the same time, inflationary pressures can compound the problem. The disruption of trade flows introduces new frictions into global supply chains, leading to increased import costs for intermediate goods and raw materials many of which are essential to Indian manufacturing. From semiconductor chips used in electronics and automotive production to critical chemicals needed in pharmaceuticals and textiles, the price volatility of imported inputs squeezed profit margins and contribute to consumer price inflation. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI), which had been signalling a neutral stand could be forced to drastically cut rates and inject liquidity into the market in a delicate balancing act needing to support growth without allowing inflation to spiral. Meanwhile, the Indian rupee can come under pressure as export earnings dips and foreign institutional investors (FIIs) adopt a risk-off approach. Uncertainty surrounding future U.S.-India trade relations can led to a short-term flight of capital, particularly from mid-cap manufacturing and tech stocks that had big US exposure. The rupee’s depreciation, while offering some buffer to exporters by improving price competitiveness, also raise the cost of oil imports and external debt servicing two perennial vulnerabilities in the Indian macroeconomic mix. The government’s response reflects both urgency and caution. On one hand, New Delhi accelerated its bilateral trade diplomacy with Washington, hoping to secure sectoral carve-outs and negotiate Bi-lateral trade agreement. On the other hand, it can initiate internal policy discussions about increasing export subsidies, expanding Production Linked Incentive (PLI) schemes, and enhancing export credit lines to cushion industries most affected by the tariff shock. However, such fiscal measures are constrained by competing budgetary pressures, including rising social sector spending and infrastructure commitments. Complicating matters further is the international optics of India's position. While it is seeking exemptions and relief from the U.S., it also has to maintain its image as a leader of the Global South, often vocal about trade equity and multilateralism. India cannot afford to appear overly compliant with American economic nationalism, lest it alienates other key partners like the European Union, ASEAN, and African nations. Balancing this diplomatic tightrope required deft maneuvering presenting itself as both a victim of unfair trade measures and a willing partner in restoring global supply chain stability. The abruptness and scale of the Trump tariffs has reawakened fears about India’s external vulnerabilities, particularly its dependence on a small number of export markets. It has reignited debates among economists, business leaders, and policymakers about the need to diversify trade relationships, boost domestic consumption, and reduce overexposure to the vicissitudes of Western politics. For all the talk of resilience, the Indian economy has once again been reminded of its susceptibility to external shocks especially those driven by populist agendas half a world away. That said, the episode is not without its silver linings. The jolt provided by the tariffs should force a re-examination of structural bottlenecks, leading to renewed urgency around trade diversification, and even prompting long-overdue upgrades in customs, compliance, and logistics infrastructure. It can also inject new life into India’s outreach to Africa and Latin America regions that, while underdeveloped in trade terms, offer the promise of growth untethered from great power rivalries. In the final tally, the Trump-era tariffs are a disruptive force, not a destructive one. They may slow growth, trigger inflationary pressures, and strained policy bandwidth, but they cannot break the Indian economy’s trajectory. Rather they can accelerate its reckoning with the global trade order and perhaps, nudge it toward a more resilient, diversified, and self-aware economic future. ### **Strategic Realignment and Trade Diplomacy: India's Response on the Global Stage** As the Trump-era tariff shock reverberates across sectors and seeped into the core of India’s macroeconomic structure, the need for a strategic recalibration of India’s external economic engagement becomes unmistakable. In the years following the first wave of U.S. tariffs during Trump’s earlier tenure, India had slowly been shifting its trade posture from passive resilience to proactive engagement. The 2025 blanket tariff escalation can catalyze this process into a full-fledged diplomatic sprint, forcing India to reassess not just its relationship with the United States, but also its positioning within the broader architecture of global trade and alliances. The initial Indian response to the tariff escalation is one of cautious pragmatism. Recognizing that aggressive retaliation could escalate the situation and derail other avenues of strategic cooperation with the U.S. particularly in defense, technology, and the Indo-Pacific security framework New Delhi has opted for a diplomatic route. Top officials from the Ministry of Commerce have been quickly dispatched to Washington for backchannel negotiations, while formal trade dialogue has resumed between two countries seeking an early resolute to trade tariffs disputes. India's core ask should be: sectoral exemptions like Agriculture, Foodstuffs & Pharma while negotiating a broader Bi-Lateral Trade Agreement with USA. Trump administration, emboldened by its ideological commitment to "reciprocity," remains insistent on more structural changes asking greater market access for American dairy, farm products, and medical devices, as well as stronger enforcement mechanisms for intellectual property rights. For India, these demands are politically sensitive, and while some flexibility may be offered behind closed doors, the broader contours of the disagreement remain on these issues. The impasse illustrates a deeper truth: U.S.-India trade tensions are no longer episodic irritants but symptomatic of deeper structural mismatches between two large, divergent economies navigating their paths through a shifting global order. In response, India should undertake a broader strategic realignment. Recognizing the risks of overexposure to any single market be it the U.S. or China, New Delhi should make efforts to diversify its trade partnerships. This includes finalizing and operationalizing free trade agreements (FTAs) with the UAE and Australia, fast-tracking negotiations with the European Union and the UK, and reopening stalled discussions with the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) and MERCOSUR nations. Each of these moves should reflect a clear policy objective: reduce vulnerability by expanding opportunity. Moreover, India should deepen its engagement with multilateral and regional trade institutions. Although it had walked away from the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) in 2020 over fears of Chinese economic dominance, India could explore revisiting its role in alternative trade blocs and frameworks. It should look with renewed interest in joining the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF), albeit selectively, and ramp up its activity within the BRICS and SCO economic platforms. These moves are not about replacing the West with the East, but about hedging risks in a multi-polar world where no single alignment offers complete security. India could also begin playing a more assertive role in setting the narrative around global trade equity. Drawing on its leadership in the Global South, it should push for reforms in the World Trade Organization (WTO) to ensure that developing countries were not disproportionately hurt by tariff wars launched by larger economies. Indian diplomats should advocate for stronger dispute resolution mechanisms and greater protection for emerging markets, framing the Trump-era tariffs not just as a bilateral dispute but as a cautionary tale for the global trading system. At the same time, India can seek to bolster domestic resilience. The idea is not to turn inward, but to prepare for a world in which trade could no longer be relied upon as an uninterrupted engine of growth. This includes greater investment in logistics infrastructure, the expansion of digital customs systems, and the implementation of trade facilitation measures aimed at reducing non-tariff barriers. The government can also begin incentivizing companies to enter new geographies offering tax breaks and marketing support for exporters targeting Latin America, Africa, and Central Asia. In essence, the Trump tariffs can be a force of good for India to shed its passive trade posture and embrace a more confident, globally aware, and multidirectional strategy. This episode must make policy makers to debates around diversification, resilience, and economic sovereignty, embedding them into the country’s long-term development playbook. And while diplomatic breakthroughs with the U.S. is still some time away, the broader trajectory of India’s trade diplomacy should be shifting from reactive negotiation to active agenda-setting. By turning crisis into opportunity, India can signal that it is no longer willing to be a price-taker in the global economy. That it wants to shape the terms of trade not just accept them. The Trump-era tariffs, harsh as they are, can become the proving ground for this new ambition. ### **China’s retaliation to Trump tariffs & the Big Tech** Globally, China has reacted to US trade tariffs of 54% by retaliating through Tariffs, Blacklists, and Trade Crackdown. China has announced to impose 34% tariff on all U.S. imports starting from April 10, 12:01 PM. Chinese customs have suspended import licenses for six U.S. companies' products. China’s ministry of commerce and customs has decided to impose export controls on rare earth minerals like Samarium, Gadolinum, Terbium, Dysprosium, Lutetium, Scandium and Yttrium. It must be noted here that China controls nearly 67% of world rare earth mineral supply so which are essential for US Department of Defence and Tech industry. As the Wall Street Journal reported, an iPhone 16 Pro (256 GB) tariffs will cost 846 dollars instead of 549 dollars due to tariffs imposed by USA which go in effect on 9th April 2025. This is due to the fact that American tech supply chain retains profitability of low-cost manufacturing in Asia of various components with cheap labour. An iPhone 16 pro for that matter has processor made in Taiwan for 90$, display in South Korea for 37$, battery in China for 4$, storage in Japan for 20$. This extra 296$ due to tariffs on these countries is what the American consumer will end up paying as American technology firms will increase prices to an extent to absorb these tariffs. This will make cost of goods expensive for American consumers adding more inflationary pressure. [![](fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fe8f9a31b-4867-44e4-baad-76f6f0b12b2f_675x1011.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2Fe8f9a31b-4867-44e4-baad-76f6f0b12b2f_675x1011.jpeg) **Source – Wall Street Journal** Dan Ives a Tech analyst on Wall Street in his note stated that Trump’s Tariffs are a black swan event for US Tech firms. He writes in his note **“Trump Tariffs will take US Tech World back a decade… China wins”**. He writes as follows: > _**“We have spoken to hundreds of investors, tech CEOs, supply chain experts around the world this week to gauge the Trump tariff Armageddon unleashed this week.In a nutshell, if these tariffs (in current form/rates) hold there is no debate...it would set the US tech world back a decade in our opinion while China is the clear winner...and we see no debate.**_ > > _**For the first time in 30 years the US is ahead of China when it comes to Al and this 4th Industrial Revolution...being led by Nvidia, Microsoft, OpenAl, Amazon, Alphabet, Palantir, Oracle, Tesla and so many others.....But in one day this tariff policy if enacted will create an upside down supply chain, massive costs, major Cap-Ex delays due to uncertainty, and slow down US tech innovation...not a debate.**_ > > _**Its very easy to say "build in America" behind a microphone in the Beltway... the reality is so much different its almost a scary concept. It takes 4-5 years to build a factory in the US, the US labor force and cost structure goes against the entire concept of the modern supply chain, much of the IP and technology fueling the supply chain is cemented in Asia, and the reality this "near-term pain" would take a decade to even move the needle.**_ > > _**If US tech companies are faced with this reality, it will negatively change the tech landscape for decades to come. The cost structure of the US tech world would make it impossible to compete with China and this would be a lotto ticket for the China tech landscape: BYD, Huawei, Alibaba, Tencent and thousands of other China tech players to gain more global market share over the years.**_ > > _**This brings us to today... the economic pain that will be brought by these tariffs are hard to describe and can essentially take the US tech industry back a decade in the process while China steamrolls ahead. 50% China tariffs, 32% Taiwan tariffs would essentially cause a shut-off valve from the US tech landscape and in the process cause every electronic to go up 40%-50% for consumers, iPhones made in the US would cost $3,500 (vs. $1,000), and the Al Revolution trade would be significantly slowed down by these head scratching tariffs that NEED to be negotiated to realistic levels. If not its darker days ahead for the tech world.**_ > > _**I have travelled millions of air miles over the decades and seen factories/technology hubs globally....the US has such an unique opportunity to further build its technology, robotics and autonomous infrastructure here...but these reciprocal tariffs (trade deficit converted into some odd calculation) implemented would cause an economic Armageddon and stop the US tech world in its tracks...and wipe out a bright future ahead in one global policy mistake that will reverse US tech dominance in our view. Stocks are getting crushed as investors know math and the reality.”**_ China in retaliation has also included 11 US entities in the list of unreliable entities. China also added 16 U.S. entities to Export Control List. China has launch of an anti-dumping investigation on imported medical CT bulbs originating in the United States and India. While the President Trump is banking on the game theory imposing tariffs and negotiating, the Chinese have retaliated knowing that America is now in a weaker position than it was say ten years back. The markets are signalling a recession and Chinese would be hoping for Trump recessions to blow apart Republicans in mid terms thus calling the bluff and not leading to submission what the US Administration seeks. Europe has also suggested taking counter measures specially on American tech companies. China has risen as a Tecno-Industrial power creating its financial architecture globally in form Digital Silk Road, integrating countries across the world in its sphere of influence. From launching Digital Yuan to AIIB to CIPS to launching Open-Source AI models to manufacturing semiconductor chips China has come a long way in challenging American dominance. The American administration needs a rude awakening that world has changed. China has risen as power in the east, Russia is not defeated in Ukraine and India is on its path to becoming the world’s third largest economy. Trade wars are nothing but pathways to ruin. What American tech needs is not protectionism but allies-shoring i.e. working with allies in Indo-Pacific to secure critical supply chains. Raising protectionist barriers will only make America an untrustworthy ally leaving vacuum for China to fill-in across vast swaths of the world. The American unilateralism should make India, Russia and other middle powers in Asia think whether America can be trusted as reliable trade partner given it is seeking to impose predatory policies to secure its interests. Thus, countries like India & Russia must push forward for a multi-polar world order amid growing bi-polarity between US & China. ### **Conclusion: The Road Ahead** The Trump-era tariffs and the broader U.S.-China trade war could leave an indelible mark on the Indian economy. What began as a distant clash between two economic titans can quickly became a global contagion of protectionism, redrawing trade routes and rewriting supply chain logic across continents. For India, this is not just a foreign policy challenge or an economic speed bump it is a strategic moment of truth. India thus should be mindful of though not retaliating to escalate things but at the same time do not give into submission of American terms & conditions for a trade deal which may go beyond tariffs into Food Security, Agriculture, Intellectual property rights and much more. India’s best policy would be to backstop its industry and manufacturing with incentives and subsidies while negotiating with USA on trade tariffs making the Trump recession play out hoping for a better deal. The macroeconomic toll of Trump tariffs and trade war on the global economy is real. Growth projections have dimmed across the world, inflation may rise again due to supply chain disruptions, and the world economy could face a prolonged recession just like the 1930s. India must bear in mind that America does not want another China in India and China also does not seek another China in Asia. Thus, while America might aim to cripple India’s manufacturing sector from Pharma to Electronics to Semi-Conductors, China on other hand seeks to curtail India’s manufacturing by withholding access to raw materials, machine parts to scale up. Trump tariffs in essence seeks to make India a trade territory for American corporates akin to pre-independence British India i.e. a frontline ally and a service backend. Trump tariffs are indeed setback to India’s dream of becoming a manufacturing powerhouse replacing China, a blue print that the Quad leaders had agreed to in 2021 in de-risking the supply chains post Covid-19. Instead of taking right approach of near shoring & ally-shoring i.e. working with allies to secure supply chains. The Trump Administration has in total disregard of the QUAD agreements, Mineral Security Partnership taken unilateral measures to take the world back to1930s by raising protectionist barriers against friends & foes alike. Several key lessons emerge for India from this the Trump tariffs saga. First, over-dependence on any single market, no matter how lucrative or historically stable, is a strategic vulnerability. India’s export ecosystem must be geographically diversified and technologically advanced, capable of withstanding sudden policy shocks. Second, sectors that rely on low-cost advantages without high-value differentiation are particularly exposed in times of geopolitical flux. The road to resilience lies in climbing the value chain, not just expanding production volume. Third, diplomacy and trade are now inseparable. Economic negotiations are increasingly being shaped by geopolitical considerations like alliances, defense pacts, technology transfer agreements and India must continue to build its leverage accordingly. Looking ahead, India stands at an inflection point. The next decade will likely be defined by the inversion of globalization, from open flows to strategic corridors, from efficiency to security, from cost arbitrage to trust-based partnerships. In this new world order, India has the opportunity to emerge not just as a substitute for China, but as a distinct economic force an engine of innovation, sustainability, and balanced growth. To do so, the country must invest aggressively in its people, its infrastructure, its digital and physical connectivity. It must build institutions that can weather international headwinds and foster a policy environment that rewards risk-taking and long-term thinking. It must see trade not as a peripheral activity, but as central to its national interest deserving of the same strategic attention as defense or energy. The Trump tariffs, as disruptive and painful as they are, offer a glimpse into the volatility of the modern economic landscape. But they also presented India with a test and, arguably, a gift. A test of resilience, of vision, of adaptability. And a gift of acceleration: a jolt that has forced uncomfortable but necessary shifts, catalyze reforms, and reveal new possibilities. In the ashes of these tariff wars, India can find a clearer sense of purpose, and a renewed determination to shape its own economic destiny and lead the world specially global south towards more equitable and fair trade. 4 2 [Share](javascript:void(0)) PreviousNext #### Discussion about this post CommentsRestacks ![User's avatar](fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack.com%2Fimg%2Favatars%2Fdefault-light.png) TopLatestDiscussions No posts Ready for more? title: US trade policy turmoil shakes the global economy, and other key economic news to know
full_text: Markets did not react well to signs of more determined US detachment from the global economy. Image: REUTERS/Amanda Perobelli ##### [Aengus Collins](https://www.weforum.org/stories/authors/aengus-collins/) Head, Economic Growth, Revival and Transformation,World Economic Forum - This regular roundup brings you essential news and updates on the global economy from the World Economic Forum’s Head of Economic Growth and Transformation. - Top stories: US tariffs overwhelm expectations; dramatic market response is followed by significant policy reversals; Germany gears up for a spending spree; and poverty reduction in India challenges development assumptions. The announcement of sweeping US tariffs on 2 April threw global trade turmoil into sharper relief, and sent markets reeling. According to [one analysis](https://www.bcg.com/publications/2025/nowhere-to-hide-tariffs-reshape-global-trade) there hadn’t been a change to the world trading system as significant since the 1947 General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs, a seminal undertaking that kickstarted a long process of undoing trade barriers. Suddenly, in tandem with other levies enacted this year, the anticipated average effective US tariff rate was pegged at 22.5% – a 20-percentage-point increase compared with the prior year, and [its highest level since 1909](https://budgetlab.yale.edu/research/where-we-stand-fiscal-economic-and-distributional-effects-all-us-tariffs-enacted-2025-through-april). The signals this sent in terms of detachment from global cooperation and the international economy in general were, to put it mildly, [not well received](https://odi.org/en/insights/us-implements-sweeping-reciprocal-tariffs-igniting-global-economic-challenges/). It took only two days for [US stocks to shed $5.4 trillion in value](https://www.ft.com/content/b1eda0a8-6449-4fe5-b8c6-a2afebadc823), equities [in Asia also tumbled](https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Markets/Asia-Pacific-stocks-sink-from-Trump-s-tariff-barrage-Hong-Kong-down-11), oil prices [hit a four-year low](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-04-06/latest-oil-market-news-and-analysis-for-april-7?embedded-checkout=true), Goldman Sachs pegged the [odds of a US recession at 45%](https://www.wsj.com/livecoverage/stock-market-trump-tariffs-trade-war-04-07-25/card/chances-of-u-s-recession-have-risen-to-45-goldman-sachs-says-8OGKnHMHECdE2nwJqEmZ), and the IMF warned of [significant risk to the global outlook](https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2025/04/03/pr2587-statement-by-imf-managing-director-kristalina-georgieva). Perhaps most importantly, a disconcerting bond-market reaction and a US dollar [trading near a three-year low](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/14/business/us-dollar-trump-tariffs.html?searchResultPosition=1) each [hinted at broader fears about American economic stability](https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2025/04/13/a-flight-from-the-dollar-could-wreck-americas-finances). On 9 April, a week after the dramatic announcement of tariffs, some were [put on a 90-day pause](https://www.wsj.com/politics/policy/why-trump-blinked-on-tariffs-b588aea8?mod=WSJ_home_supertoppermiddle_pos_3) – providing only a brief respite. China saw its tariffs raised to [a cumulative 145%](https://www.wsj.com/livecoverage/stock-market-trump-tariffs-trade-war-04-10-25/card/trump-tariffs-on-china-actually-145-says-white-house-3vTUxU4R2ZHKFMcEsoW6) and responded in kind, before a [batch of selective exemptions](https://www.ft.com/content/3eb48a07-7cb0-4a44-9159-eb5b402c2fec) from the US side further muddied the waters. Experts [struggled to find anyone](https://www.wsj.com/economy/trade/us-china-tariffs-trade-war-6f143252?mod=WSJ_home_mediumtopper_pos_2) who stands to benefit from this burgeoning trade war, as other parts of the world sorted through [additional US tariffs](https://www.axios.com/2025/04/09/trump-tariffs-90-day-pause-china) applied separately to cars and vital commodities. Markets remain unsettled amid alarming projections. This is not just a reaction to tariffs themselves, whether enacted or suspended. It’s a response to a profound sense of policy uncertainty, and a signal of mounting concern over slowing growth, higher inflation, and deteriorating economic conditions. ##### Have you read? - ##### [How impacted is your country by the Trump tariffs?](https://www.weforum.org/stories/2025/04/how-impacted-your-country-us-trump-tariffs/) - ##### [Europe just might be ‘uniquely well positioned’ to manage a tariff war](https://www.weforum.org/stories/2025/04/liberation-day-europe-economics-tariffs/) - ##### [Navigating Asia's new trade reality after the US tariff shock](https://www.weforum.org/stories/2025/04/navigating-asia-new-trade-reality-after-the-us-tariff-shock/) ## Responses in the US and elsewhere In the US, some lawmakers in President Donald Trump’s own party sought to give Congress a bigger role in authorizing new tariffs. A [legal nonprofit was retained](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/04/05/trump-tariffs-sink-conservatives-challenge-whether-theyre-legal/) to file a complaint challenging the legality of the levies targeting Chinese imports. Meanwhile polling suggested that [a vast majority of American voters](https://www.wsj.com/livecoverage/stock-market-trump-tariffs-trade-war-04-09-25/card/poll-shows-majority-think-trump-tariffs-will-hurt-u-s-economy-TVSXGKNDzm4TqNxnlVOl) think the new US tariffs will hurt the country’s economy in the short-term – and reflected the [largest share of Americans expecting higher inflation](https://today.yougov.com/politics/articles/51986-donald-trump-declining-popularity-tariffs-third-term-the-economy-april-5-8-2025-economist-yougov-poll) since 2022. Reactions abroad ranged [from retaliation to attempted conciliation](https://globaltradealert.org/reports/governments-responses-to-the-US-Reciprocal-Tariffs). Some places, like the European Union, [pursued a bit of both](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/07/world/europe/europe-tariffs-trump-response.html). Canada said it was responding to “ [unwarranted and unjustified tariffs](https://www.pm.gc.ca/en/news/news-releases/2025/04/03/canada-announces-new-countermeasures-response-tariffs-from-united-states)” with a 25% levy of its own on US goods. Members of ASEAN, which were confronted with particularly steep and uneven suspended levies as high as 49%, opted to pursue diplomatic responses while [pushing for a unified regional strategy](https://www.aseanbriefing.com/news/aseans-response-to-u-s-tariffs-toward-a-unified-regional-strategy/) that includes leaning more heavily on commerce with one another. They may also now pursue [deeper economic integration with China](https://www.chathamhouse.org/2025/04/trumps-tariffs-will-push-southeast-asia-uncomfortably-close-china). ## What comes next? The EU is pursuing its own diplomatic responses. It paused its own tariffs applied in response to US levies on steel and aluminium, while [nearing a free-trade agreement with India](https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2025/03/can-geopolitical-alignment-seal-the-india-eu-fta?lang=en) and [subtly flagging](https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-pencils-in-china-summit-for-july/) a potential summit with leaders from Beijing this summer. Central banks are keeping a watchful eye on things. An interest-rate cut from the European Central Bank [seems imminent](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-04-09/ecb-has-no-reason-to-cut-interest-rates-now-holzmann-says). In the US, where projected impacts of the upheaval included a [loss of about 740,000 jobs over the coming decade](https://taxfoundation.org/research/all/federal/trump-tariffs-trade-war/), central bankers [signaled that an interest rate cut is unlikely](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-04-13/kashkari-says-all-the-fed-can-do-is-keep-inflation-anchored) for now. Analysts indicated that the poorest economies are likely to be hit hardest by the tariff wave. This could cause [lasting harm to US standing in the developing world](https://www.piie.com/blogs/realtime-economics/2025/trumps-april-2-tariff-spree-could-cripple-developing-economies). ## News in brief: other global economic stories - Recent survey data reveal [dramatic progress made in India](https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2025/02/27/india-has-undermined-a-popular-myth-about-development) on reducing extreme poverty – challenging traditional assumptions about how development happens. - A new UN report warned that many countries in the Asia-Pacific region [remain ill-prepared](https://www.unescap.org/kp/2025/survey2025) for climate-related economic shocks. - The IMF-World Bank Spring Meetings are fast approaching, and on 17 April IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva will set out [the latest outlook](https://www.imf.org/en/News/Articles/2025/04/17/sp041725-spring-meetings-2025-curtain-raiser) for the embattled global economy. - The incoming German government published its [coalition agreement](https://www.ft.com/content/13104190-f2d8-4296-8584-05574e5706f2), following last month’s historic deal to loosen the country’s constitutional debt brake. Ramping up public spending could boost the wider European economy, but [it won’t be without challenges](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-04-07/germany-s-merz-has-a-problem-can-he-spend-a-trillion-euros). - The OECD published its [Global Debt Report for 2025](https://www.oecd.org/en/publications/2025/03/global-debt-report-2025_bab6b51e.html); it projected a record year for the issuance of sovereign bonds amid rising interest costs. ##### Share: ##### Contents [Responses in the US and elsewhere](https://www.weforum.org/www.weforum.org#responses-in-the-us-and-elsewhere) [What comes next?](https://www.weforum.org/www.weforum.org#what-comes-next?)
